She invests the income that she accrues from her job into her cosmetics business, in so doing generating a bit more revenue to help her family get ahead. She hopes to one day move her business forward and make a living off of it alone. However, she is now concerned with her house. She needs a loan in order to roof her patio because during winter, her home’s interior is affected by water that leaks in.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria Andrea es una mujer que a sus 37 años de edad se desempeña como trabajadora doméstica, es soltera y por toda una vida le ha tocado velar por la vida de sus tres hijos ella sola. Ahora tiene a su cargo solamente a dos hijos los cuales estudian y a los cuales ella espera poder ayudarlos para que terminen su educación y sean hombres de bien.

Del salario que ella devenga ha invertido en el negocio de venta de cosméticos para así generar un poco más de ingresos y poder sacar adelante a su familia. Espera algund dia poder sacar adealnte su negocio y vivir solamente de él. Pero ahora su preocupación es su casa de habitación, requiere del préstamo pra techar el area del patio de su casa de habitación, yaque con el invierno el interior de su casa se ve afectado, debido a que el agua se mete en su vivienda.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to roof her courtyard

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Alba Nubia

texts.es:
Ms. Alba T. is a married, 35-year-old mother of three (ages 4, 6, & 10) who lives in the Waspan Norte neighborhood. Her husband works as an agriculturist and contributes to the household expenses.

Ms. T. sells assorted products by credit. She has eight years of experience in the business. She started the business with loans, and it was been growing ever since. She wants to invest this new loan in the purchase of more products to offer her customers because she wishes to increase her merchandise variety and attract even more customers.

She plans to keep investing into her business, provide an education for her children, and improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Alba tiene 35 años de edad, habita en el barrio Waspan Norte, es casada y tiene tres hijos de 4, 6 y 10 años de edad, su esposo trabaja como Ing. Agrónomo y aporta a los gastos del hogar.

Doña Alba vende mercadería variada al crédito, y lleva ocho años de experiencia, ella inició con préstamos y ha ido creciendo. Con el préstamo que está solicitando es para invertir en capital, en la compra de más productos para ofrecer a sus clientes, variedad de mercadería y la captación de clientes.

Sus planes son seguir invirtiendo en su negocio, educar a sus hijos y mejorar el nivel de vida.

loans.use: Purchase a variety of merchandise to offer to her customers

loans.name: Johanna

texts.es:
Johanna is a married 34-year-old mother who lives in the Waspan Norte neighborhood of the city of Managua. She has two children ages 12 and 14. Her husband helps her with the family expenses with the income he earns from his business—a shop in one of the city’s markets.

Johanna runs her own general store in her house. She has three years of experience, during which time she has been able to develop her business and meet her customers’ needs. Johanna lives in an impoverished neighborhood in which the residents buy what they need on a daily basis.

For this reason, Johanna needs to offer a variety of goods in her business so that she can meet customer demand and thus maintain her profits. She plans to be able to have a well-established business and take advantage of its location so that she can boost sales.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Johanna tiene 34 años de edad, es casada y habita en el barrio Waspan Norte de la ciudad de Managua, tiene dos hijos de 12 y 14 años de edad. Su esposo apoya a los gastos de la familia a través de los ingresos generados por su negocio, que es comercio en un mercado de la ciudad.

Johanna tiene una pulpería en su casa de habitación, y tiene tres años de experiencia, en los cuales ha podido desarrollarse y satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes. El lugar donde habita Johanna es un barrio pobre, la forma de consumo de los habitantes es la compra diaria de los alimentos que consumen.

Es por eso que Johanna necesita mantener variado su negocio para tener que ofertar a sus clientes y así poder mantener siempre sus ganancias. Sus planes son poder establecer su negocio y aprovechar la ubicación geográfica para así poder sacar el mejor provecho y aumentar su nivel de ventas.

loans.use: Purchase cleaning products and staple grains for general store

loans.name: Pastora

texts.es:
Pastora is a seamstress with 30 years of experience. From a young age, she learned how to sew in order to help support her family. Over time and after seeing the need to be independent and form her own family, Pastora decided to invest her savings in the purchase of the equipment she needed to become a seamstress. Pastora is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood. Her husband is retired, so he receives a pension with which he helps his wife cover the household expenses.

Pastora currently lives alone with her husband, which is why she would like to improve her house in order to spend a peaceful old age with her husband. For the moment, however, she wants to focus all her efforts on setting up a clothing factory, which is why she is requesting a loan in order to purchase fabric and continue offering her customers a variety of styles and colors.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Pastora es una costurera con 30 años de experiencia. Desde muy joven aprendió a hacer costuras para ayudar a mantener a su familia, pero con el tiempo y en vista de la necesidad de independizarse y formar su propia familia Pastora decidió invertir sus ahorros en compra de accesorios para poder desempeñarse como costurera. Pastora tiene 44 años de edad, habita en el barrio Laureles Sur, es casada, su esposo es mayor de edad, recibe una pensión y le ayuda a su esposa con los gastos del hogar.

Actualmente Pastora vive sola con su marido, es por eso que desea poder darle condiciones a su casa para poder pasar junto a su esposo una vejez tranquila. Pero por el momento se dedicará a enfocar su esfuerzo en llegar a poner un taller de confecciones, es por eso que solicita el préstamo para poder adquirir telas para seguir ofreciendo a sus clientes variedad de estilos y colores.

loans.use: Purchase fabric

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Marie Brigitte

texts.fr:
Marie Brigitte N., 50, is a divorced mother of six and has been a member of the Néma 2 village bank for five years. She would like to buy palm oil, honey, lemons and undergarments (bras and slips). She buys the palm oil and undergarments in Guinea and then sells them in Cap Skiring. Marie also works as a maid. She would like to develop her business to better cover her family’s food, health and education expenses. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid in six months in one single installment.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Marie Brigitte N., 50 ans, divorcée avec 06 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Néma 2 depuis 5 ans. Elle veut acheter de l’huile de palme, du miel, du citron et du linge de corps (soutien gorge et slip). Elle achète l’huile et le linge de corps en guinée pour revendre au Cap Skiring. Marie travaille aussi comme domestique. Elle veut renforcer son commerce pour améliorer la prise en charge des besoins de nourriture, de santé et de scolarité de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Sale of honey, palm oil, lemons and undergarments

loans.name: Antonia Teresa

texts.es:
Antonia belongs to the "Working Women" Commual Bank. She is married and 73 years old; she studied until 4th grade and has 7 children who live on their own. She lives in the Mache district in the province of Trujillo, La Libertad. Her primary occupation is selling firewood. She buys the wood in Julcan and sells it in Trujillo (in the Hermelinda market). When there is a shortage of firewood, she does other jobs (she buys used truck batteries and sells them for a higher price). With her first loan, she bought firewood and earned greater profits. With this loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy scrap metal and batteries. She is thinking of requesting another loan to purchase wheat and "chocho" (a grain cultivated in South America). Antonia will continue working with Manuela Ramos because now she is more independent. Before, she didn't work; with the loan, she invests in her business and feels useful. She earns a profit of S/5.00 (daily) from her business. She decided to request the loan to improve her quality of life. Her goal is keep working and not depend on anyone.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Antonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres de Trabajo, esta casada, tiene 73 años; estudió hasta 4to grado de primaria. Tiene 07 hijos que ya son independientes. Vive en el distrito de Mache Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad. Su actividad principal es el comercio de leña. Ella compra este producto en Julcan, y lo vende en la ciudad de Trujillo (mercado La Hermelinda). En tiempo de escasez de leña, se dedica a otro negocio (compra batería de camión usada y lo vende a un mayor precio). El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00, el cual invirtió en la compra de leña, logró obtener mejores ganancias. Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, el cual será pagado en 04 meses, comprará fierros y baterías. Piensa solicitar otros S/. 3,000.00, para invertir en grano de trigo y de chocho. La señora Antonia, seguirá trabajando con Manuela Ramos, porque ahora es más independiente, antes no salía a trabajar, a través del préstamo invierte en el negocio y obtiene utilidad. El beneficio que logra por producto, es de S/5.00 (diario). Decidió solicitar el préstamo para mejorar su calidad de vida. Tiene como meta seguir trabajando y no depender de nadie.

loans.use: To purchase scrap metal and batteries.

loans.name: Mariama Mama

texts.fr:
Mariama Mama S., 46, is a married mother of three and has been a member of the Kadior village bank for five years. She would like to purchase dyed cloth “boubous,” or gowns, and then sell them in Ziguinchor. The income she earns allows her to help pay her family members’ daily expenses and improve their quality of life and health. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid in six months in one single installment.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mariama Mama S., 46 ans, mariée, 03 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Kadior depuis 5 ans. Elle veut acheter des boubous en tissu teinté et revendre à Ziguinchor. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent de participer à la dépense quotidienne et d’améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Purchase and sale of dyed “boubous,” or gowns

loans.name: Full Contact Group

texts.en:
Anouse J. lives in Troud du Nord, Haiti, the poorest country in the western hemisphere.  Desperate times call for great measures and Anouse took the opportunity to receive a loan to begin her small business.  At just fourteen, Anouse has already accepted and paid off one loan in full.  She is now asking for her second loan from Esperanza International.  The money from this loan will go towards purchasing more cosmetics that she is able to sell in the streets of Haiti.  This loan has made it possible for Anouse to earn enough money to live on and even begin to save.  She dreams of one day owning her own house.

Anouse J. is the leader of the 10 person micro-bank, Full Contact.  Each of these unique Haitian entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own.  The concept of this group paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the others members gladly help cover one another’s payments in order to receive their next loan together. Like Anouse, most of these entrepreneurs dream of someday owning their own house, an impressive goal in a country that is filled with slum lords and oppression, a goal that will provide a future for families and communities in these areas

On behalf of Anouse, the Full Contact group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, in which your efforts are helping to make a difference.

loans.use: Make up, nail polish, and other cosmetics.

loans.name: Sounkar

texts.fr:
Sounkar S., 45, is a married mother of four and a member of the Kadior village bank. Her business consists of buying cloth to make clothing, bags and tablecloths. The income she earns allows her to pay her family members’ daily expenses and improve their quality of life. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid in six months in one single installment.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Sounkar S., 45 ans, mariée, 04 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Kadior. Elle mène une activité qui consiste à acheter des tissus pour confectionner des habits, des sacs et des nappes de table . Ses revenus lui permettent de participer à la dépense quotidienne et d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Making and selling clothing, bags and tablecloths

loans.name: Flor Violeta

texts.es:
Flor is 23 years old and married. She is a member of the "Working Women" Communal Bank. She studied until the third grade and has 2 small children. She lives in the Mache district in the province of Trujillo, La Libertad. Her primary occupation is selling guinea pigs, chickens, sheep, and small animals. She buys and sells her livestock in Julcan. With her first loan, she invested in this small business. With this loan of $725.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy roof tiles to set up her business. Later, she is thinking of requesting another loan to continue working and increase capital. Flor will continue working with Manuela Ramos. Thanks to the loans she has received she has been able to increase her income and now sells six sheep per week. She decided to request this loan because the goal of the bank members who encouraged her to participate is to buy land for a small farm.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Flor, esta casada, tiene 23 años; pertenece al Banco Comunal “MUJERES DE TRABAJO”. Estudió hasta 3er año de secundaria, tiene 02 hijos pequeños. Vive en el distrito de Mache Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad. Su actividad principal es el comercio de cuyes, gallinas, ovejas, animales pequeños. Ella compra y vende en Julcan. El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00, el cual invirtió en un pequeño negocio. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, el cual será pagado en un plazo de 04 meses; comprará teja para implementar su negocio. Mas adelante piensa solicitar S/. 2,000.00, para seguir trabajando e incrementar el capital. La señora Flor, seguirá trabajando con Manuela Ramos, gracias a los prestamos recibidos ha podido incrementar sus ingresos, ahora vende 6 ovejas por semana. Decidió solicitar el préstamo, porque los socios la impulsaron a participar, tiene como meta, comprar un terreno en la chacra.

loans.use: To purchase roof tiles.

loans.name: Edita Graciela

texts.es:
Edita belongs to the Bellavista Communal Bank. She is 59 years old and married; she studied until the second grade, has one child, and is independent. She lives in the district of Esperanza in the province of Trujillo, La Libertad. Her primary occupation is preparing meals. Edita buys ingredients from the Hermelinda market and prepares chicken and meat soups. It's a traveling stall in the Bellavista market. With her first loan of S/.300.00, she invested in the purchase of rice, noodles, pots, etc.. With her loan of S /. 1200.00, which will be paid within 6 months, she will buy rice, potatoes, chicken, vegetables, etc.. She is thinking of a requesting another loan of S/.1500.00 to establish her own stall at the market. The personal challenge that this entrepreneur faces is moving her business forward. Edita would be willing to continue working with Manuela Ramos because the loans are sufficient, and they have helped her increase her income. Her daily profit is approximately S/60.00. She decided to request a loan to survive during the economic crisis. Her long-term goal is to have her own restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Edita, pertenece al Banco Comunal Bellavista,. Está casada, tiene 59 años; estudió hasta 2do grado de primaria, tiene 01 hijo, es independiente. Vive en el distrito de La Esperanza Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad. Su actividad principal es la preparación de comidas. La señora Edita compra los ingredientes en el mercado La Hermelinda y prepara caldo de gallina y de carne, ella realiza su actividad de forma ambulante en el mercado Bellavista. El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00, el cual invirtió en la compra de arroz, fideo, ollas, etc. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,200.00, el cual será pagado en un plazo de 06 meses; comprará arroz, papa, pollo, verduras, etc. Piensa solicitar S/.1500.00, para tener un puesto propio. El desafío personal que la empresaria hace frente es, salir adelante. La señora Edita, sí estaría dispuesta a seguir trabajando con Manuela Ramos, porque los créditos son suficientes y han ayudado a incrementar sus ingresos. La ganancia diaria es aproximadamente de S/60.00. Decidió solicitar el préstamo para sobresalir de la crisis económica. Tiene como meta tener un restaurant propio.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to prepare meals.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria is married, she is 56 years old; she didn’t finish school, has 9 kids, although only 3 live with her. She lives in the district of La Esperanza, Province of Trujillo, La Libertad. She sells groceries. Her partner buys products at the Hermelinda’s market and sells them at the Bellavista market. The first loan she received of S/.300.00 (Soles), she invested it on buying spices. She Belongs to the Community Bank called “Bellavista II” recently she received a loan of $1,200, which will be paid on 4 months; with this loan she will buy rice, sugar, oil, pasta and some of it will be invested on the construction of her store. She is looking to request a S/.1,500 (Soles) loan to supply better her business. Her personal challenge is to increase her savings to have access to larger credit. Mrs. Maria is willing to keep on working with Manuela Ramos (Feminist Peruvian organization), but she is requesting a larger loan, because previous loans were not enough. The profit she gets per unit of product is S/.0.10 (Soles), getting a daily profit of approximately S/ 5.00 to S/.10.00 Soles. She decided to solicit the loan because of lack of her own economic resources. One of obstacles she has faced is higher prices of products. Her goal is to have her own store.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María está casada, tiene 56 años; no tiene grado D. instrucción, tiene 09 hijos, solo 03 son dependientes. Vive en el distrito D. La Esperanza Provincia D. Trujillo, La Libertad. Su actividad principal es vender abarrotes. La socia compra los productos en el mercado La Hermelinda y los venD. en el mercado Bellavista. El primer préstamo que recibió fue D. S/.300.00, el cual invirtió en la compra D. condimentos, ajino moto, etc. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “BELLAVISTA II ”, recientemente ha recibido un préstamo D. S/. 1,200.00, el cual será pagado en un plazo D. 04 meses; con este préstamo comprará arroz, azúcar, aceite, tallarín, y una parte la invertirá en la construcción del local. Piensa solicitar S/. 1,500.00 para surtir mejor el negocio. El desafío personal que la empresaria hace frente, es incrementar el ahorro para acceder a un mayor crédito. La señora María, sí, estaría dispuesta a seguir trabajando con Manuela Ramos, pero solicita que le otorguen un préstamo mayor, porque los créditos no son suficientes. El beneficio que logra por unidad D. producto es D. S/.0.10, obteniendo una ganancia diaria aproximadamente D. S/ 5.00 a S/.10.00 soles. Por falta D. recursos económicos, decidió solicitar el préstamo. Una D. las dificultades que se han presentado es el alza D. precios. Tiene como meta, construir un puesto que sea propio.

loans.use: To buy diverse grocery products at wholesale prices / Compra al por mayor de artículos diversos (abarrotes).

loans.name: Taisisi

texts.en:
Taisisi M., 58, is married with six children and lives in the Vaitele area of Upolu Island, Samoa. She has many years of experience in the flea market business, selling clothing to the general public and villagers 5 days per week.

Taisisi has had a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be about 450 Tala ($187 US). SPBD loans are Taisisi’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this new loan for purchase clothing and handicrafts for resale.

loans.use: Purchase inventory.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita P., 31, is married with 5 children and lives in the Vaitele area of Upolu Island, Samoa. She has many years of experience operating a general store, from which she sells to the general public and villagers 7 days a week.

Anita has a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (US$208). SPBD loans are Anita’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase sacks of sugar, rice, salt, and flour, as well as tinned goods and soft drinks for resale.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Nive

texts.en:
Nive U., 35, is married with 3 children and lives in the Vailele area of Upolu Island, Samoa. She has 3 years of experience making and selling "ice cakes" (flavored ices) to the general public and villagers 5 days per week.

Nive has had two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Nive’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase plastic cups, concentrated flavors, and sugar for her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for flavored ices

loans.name: Faafeai

texts.en:
Faafeai T., 69, is a single woman with 7 children. She has many years of experience growing taro root and other vegetables that she sells to the general public and villagers two days per week.

Faafeai has had two previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (US$145). SPBD loans are Faafeai’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase taro tubers, pesticides, chemicals and vegetable seeds.

loans.use: To support the cultivation of taro and other vegetables.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Mrs. Teresa is married and is 62 years old. She studied elementary school and hast 4 kids who are independent now. She lives in the district of La Esperanza, Province of Trujillo, La Libertad. She belongs to the Community Bank of “Bellavista”. Her main activity is selling groceries. She buys the products in the Hermelinda market and sells them in a grocery store installed in her own home. The first loan she received was for S/.300.00 (Soles), which she invested on buying new products. With this loan of S/ .800.00, which will be pay in 6 months; she will buy rice, oil, sugar, milk, etc. She is planning to request S/. 1,000.00 to supply her business. Mrs. Teresa, would be willing to keep on working with Manuela Ramos (Feminist Peruvian organization), but she requests a larger loan, because the loans are not enough. She decided to request the loan to get independence, and her goal is to have a Minimarket.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Teresa, esta casada y tiene 62 años. Estudió primaria completa y tiene 04 hijos que ya son independientes. Vive en el distrito D. La Esperanza Provincia D. Trujillo, La Libertad. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “BELLAVISTA”. Su actividad principal es el comercio D. abarrotes. La socia compra los productos en el mercado La Hermelinda y venD. en la bodega instalada en su propia casa. El primer préstamo que recibió fue D. S/.300.00, el cual invirtió en la compra D. mercadería. Con este préstamo D. S/ .800.00, el cual será pagado en un plazo D. 06 meses; comprará arroz, aceite, azúcar, leche, etc. Piensa solicitar S/. 1,000.00 para surtir el negocio. El desafío personal que la empresaria hace frente es la superación. La señora Teresa, sí estaría dispuesta a seguir trabajando con Manuela Ramos, pero solicita que le otorguen un préstamo mayor, porque los créditos no son suficientes. Decidió solicitar el préstamo, para independizarse, tiene como meta tener un Minimarket.

loans.use: To buy several products at wholesale prices / Compra al por mayor de diversos productos.

loans.name: Lagi

texts.en:
Lagi F., 40, is married with 5 children and lives in Vaitele on the island of Upolu, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience making hand-painted clothing that she sells in a flea market to the general public six days per week. Her husband helps her run her business.

Lagi has had a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (US$104). SPBD loans are Lagi’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of this loan will be used for her children's school fees and renovating her house. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase fabric, fabric paints, and brushes for painting clothing for sale.

loans.use: To purchase materials for hand-painted clothing

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Sara L., 27, is married with 5 children and lives at Seesee on Upolu Island, Samoa. She has been making the traditional printed fabric called "elei" for a year. She sells to the public and villagers 3 days per week.

Sara is asking for her first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (US$145). SPBD loans are Sara’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to buy equipment (paint, material, brushes, etc) for the production of elei material.

loans.use: Purchase Use for buying paintings, materials, brushes and elei woods

loans.name: Mau

texts.en:
Mau M., 31, is married with 3 children and lives at Moamoa on Upolu Island, Samoa. Her husband works as a carpenter and she has begun a business making and selling "ice cakes" (flavored ices) to the public and villagers 6 days per week.

This will be Mau's first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Mau’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase plastic cups and the ingredients for her ice cakes.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for flavored ices.

loans.name: Selesa

texts.en:
Selesa P., 31, is married with 7 children and lives in Moamoa, Upolu Island, Samoa. Her husband is a mechanic and Selesa has decided to start a business seling "ice cakes" (flavored ice) and sandwiches. She sells to the public and schoolchildren 5 days per week.

This loan will be Selesa's first with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Selesa’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase plastic cups, sugar, and cordials for the ice cakes and bread and herring for the sandwiches.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for ice cakes and sandwiches

loans.name: Opeta

texts.en:
Opeta O., 46, is married with 6 children and lives in Puipaa, Upolu Island, Samoa. She has 4 years of experience in the fishing business, which she practices together with her husband. She sells to the general public and villagers 3 days per week.

Opeta has had four previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Opeta’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use her loan to purchase fishing equipment including nets, a canoe, and hooks, and the rest to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: To pay for fishing equipment and school fees

loans.name: Faasalusalu

texts.en:
Faasalusalu F., 35, is married with 2 children and lives at Vailele on the island of Upolu, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience growing giant taro ("taro taamu") and bananas that she sells to villagers and the general public 3 days per week.

Faasalusalu has had a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Faasalusalu’s only access to capital because she was has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase chemicals and pesticides for her business.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and pesticides for farming

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Mrs. Bertha, is a member of the Community Bank Molino of the Molino town, from the Juli district and province of Chucuito Juli, department of Puno. She harvests trout and sells groceries; her store is located in Sihuayro. She is 39 years old, studied elementary school, is mother of 4 kids and her husband lives in Tacna (another town) working for a company a year ago. She requested a loan because of lack of her own capital to improve the production of trout and her business, she received since 2006 S/. 300.00 new Soles, and she bought 7 sacks of food for trout. With this loan of S/. 800.00 new Soles, which will be paid in 4 months, she will buy 100 kilograms of rice, 2 bags of pasta, 100 kilograms of flour, a box of oil, among other things, so she will be able to increase her products and is very satisfied with the loan because it helps her improve her economic resources.
Her future vision is to be a entrepreneur and to export trout to other national and international markets.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Bertha, es socia del Banco Comunal Molino del Centro Poblado Molino, del distrito de Juli y provincia de Chucuito Juli del departamento de Puno. Se dedica a la crianza de trucha y venta de abarrotes ubicado en la localidad de Sihuayro. Ella tiene 39 años de edad, estudió hasta quinto de primaria, es madre de 4 hijos y su esposo vive en Tacna trabajando en una empresa hace un año. Accedió al crédito por falta del capital para mejorar su producción de trucha y su negocio, recibiendo desde 2006 la suma de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con el cual compro 7 sacos de alimentos de trucha. Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, compró 1 quintal de arroz, 2 bolsas de fideos, un quintal de Harina, una caja de aceite y entre otros, con ello logró incrementar su mercadería y está muy satisfecha con el préstamo porque ayuda a mejorar sus ingresos económicos. Su visión futura esta enmarcado en ser empresaria y exportador de trucha a los mercados nacionales e internacionales.

loans.use: To buy diverse grocery products at wholesale prices / Compra al por mayor de productos diversos.

loans.name: Petivia

texts.en:
Petivia S., 35, is married with 3 children and lives at Vailele, Upolu Island, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience selling barbecued foods to the villagers and the general public 3 days per week.

Petivia has a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Petivia’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase mutton flaps (high-fat cuts of sheep), chicken franks, soya, onions, and salt for her barbecue.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for barbecue

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy clothing products at wholesale prices / Compra de prendas de vestir al por mayor.

loans.name: Tania Isabel

texts.en:
Tania is 36 years old and single. She belongs to the Tulipanes Village Bank and earns income running her own store from her home. At the store, Tania sells icecream, clothes, jewelry, cosmetics, groceries, and various gifts. She also rents out costumes and dolls, and is gradually expanding her business even further.

Tania currently needs a loan to buy pants, poloshirts and glasses for sale.

In the future, she hopes to be able to offer a greater variety of produtcs in her shop and thus improve her financial stability.

loans.use: Purchase of pants, poloshirts, and glasses for sale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha belongs to the Tulipanes Village Bank.

She is married, is 37 and has 3 children. She has a clothes workshop in a rented place. She makes and mends clothes. Martha changed of place 2 months ago and thus improved her sales. She also sells spare parts she purchases in Lima and then sells in her store. She began doing this because her husband is a mechanic. She realizes both activities in the same place.

Martha needs a 1600 soles loan to buy different types of spare parts.

She would like to extend her business, to have a bigger store and hire people to help her.

Click here to see Martha's first loan.

loans.use: Martha needs a 1600 soles loan to buy different types of spare parts.

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Petrona is 57 years old, she couldn’t studied, she only speaks Aymara and understands little Spanish, is married and has 9 children who are now independent, lives in the neighborhood of Miraflores in Santa Rosa village in the district of Yunguyo.

She buys and sells cows and pigs, which she acquires at the Yunguyo fair, for the last fifteen years.

She belongs to the community bank “Tupac Amaru” and got a loan of S/. 300.00 new soles, which she invested on buying four pigs.

With this loan of S/. 1,000.00 new soles, which will be paid in 4 months she will buy a small bull she will fat in and later on sell.

Her greatest dream is that her kids work and be financially. well

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

Petrona tiene 57 años D. edad, no logro estudiar, habla solo el aymará y entienD. poco castellano, es casada y tiene nueve hijos que ya son independientes, vive en el Barrio Miraflores en Villa Santa Rosa del distrito D. Yunguyo. Se dedica a la compra y venta D. vacas y chanchos, para engorD., que los adquiere y venD. en la feria D. Yunguyo, actividad a la que se dedica desD. hace quince años. Pertenece al banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru”, inicio con un crédito D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra D. cuatro chanchos. Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compró un torete para engorD. que después será vendido. El gran sueño que tiene es que sus hijos trabajen y estén bien económicamente.

loans.use: To buy cattle / Compra de ganado.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.en:
María is 26 years old, married, and has a child. She belongs to the Tulipanes Village Bank and earns income running her own grocery store which is located in a rented house. María has only recently started to mill cereals to produce various types of flour. She sells these products in her store or delivers them to her neighbours and friends. María is currently renting the mill that she uses for flour production, and this activity helps her earn additional income.

Presently, María needs a loan to buy wheat, corn, rice and barley.

In the future, she hopes to expand her business and to buy her own house.

loans.use: Purchase of wheat, corn, rice and barley

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is 31 years old, married, and has 3 children. She belongs to the Aleli Village Bank. She owns a store where she sells not only groceries, gas, and various gifts, but also firewood. She has expanded her business in the last few months and bought more display cabinets to better present her products and thus increase the sales volume. Doris currently needs a loan to buy beer, fizzy drinks and gas for sale in her store.

In the future, Doris hopes to expand her house and have a bigger store to earn more income and help pay for her children's education.

loans.use: Purchase of beer, fizzy drinks, and gas for a retail business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia is 37 years old, and couldn’t finish high school, she speaks Aymara and Spanish, is married and has 5 children, 3 of them are in high school, one is on elementary school and the youngest is still a baby. She lives on the neighborhood of Progreso Jr. Manco Capac s/n, in the village of Chipana, district of Pilcuyo, province of El Collao.

She works preparing and selling bread, and takes her products every day to the market, and works on this activity for the last 17 years.

She belongs to the community bank “Lago Azul” where she started with a loan of S/. 300.00 new soles that she invested on buying a sack of flour and a ball of yeast.

With the loan of S/. 1,700.00 new soles, that will be paid in 3 months, she will buy 3 sacks of flour, a ball of yeast, a sack of sugar and ten bags of salt and firewood.

She is very thankful with the loan she received because it increased her income and learned to be responsible and punctual with her payments.

Her greatest wish is that her kids one day could be professionals and work. She would like to continue her business.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

Sonia tiene 37 años de edad, estudio hasta el cuarto de secundaria, habla el aymará y castellano, es casada tiene cinco hijos, tres estudian en el Colegio, uno en la escuela y un bebe, ella vive en el Barrio progreso Jr. Manco Cápac s/n, en Villa Chipana Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia de El Collao. Se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pan, llevando sus productos todos los días a Ilave se dedica a esta actividad hace 17 años. Pertenece al banco Comunal “Lago Azul” donde inició con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra de un saco de harina y una bola de levadura. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 3 meses, compró tres sacos de harina, una bolsa de levadura, un saco de azúcar, diez bolsitas de sal y leña. Esta muy agradecida con el crédito recibido porque mejoró sus ingresos económicos y aprendió a ser responsable y puntual en sus pagos. El gran anhelo que tiene, es que sus hijos sean profesionales y trabajen. A ella le gustaría continuar con el negocio.

loans.use: To buy at wholesale prices flour, yeast and other products. / Compra al por mayor de harina, levadura y otros insumos.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es:
Paulina is 43 years old. She was unable to get an education, speaks only Aymara (indigenous language) and is married. She has three children that are studying, lives in the Caluyo sector in Santa Rosa Village, Yunguyo District

Paulina is dedicated to sell cows, sheep, and pigs and activity that she started at a young age. She sells them at the Chacacha and Yunguyo fairs. She belongs to the "Tupac Amaru" Communal Bank where she obtained an initial loan of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency). She used it to be three sheep. With this new loan of S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency), which she will pay back in 4 months, Paulina will buy 4 pigs and 3 sheep that she will sell after they are fatten. Being a member of the communal bank, Paulina learned to be responsible with her payments. Her greatest wish is to be able to support her children and be able to see them as professionals with a good job.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Paulina tiene 43 años D. edad, no logro estudiar, habla solo el idioma aymará, es casada y tiene tres hijos que están estudiando, vive en el sector Caluyo , en Villa Santa Rosa del distrito D. Yunguyo. Paulina se dedica a la venta D. vacas, ovejas y chanchos, que los venD. en las ferias D. Chacachaca y Yunguyo, actividad a la que se dedica desD. muy joven. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” donD. tuvo un crédito inicial D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra D. tres ovejas. Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, compró 4 chanchos y 3 ovejas que serán vendidas después del engorD.. Siendo socia del banco comunal aprendió a ser solidaria y responsable en sus pagos. El gran anhelo que ella tiene, es apoyar a sus hijos a que sean profesionales y que tengan un buen trabajo.

loans.use: Buying cattle (pigs and sheep)

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Carolina is 32 years old, has 2 children, and lives with her husband. She earns income selling clothes, shoes, wax, and cochineal to her friends and relatives, either on credit or for cash. Depending on the demand, Carolina also sells meals, especially during parties and fairs.

Carolina belongs to the Alborada Village Bank. Currently, she needs a loan of US$450 to buy more wax, cochineal, and leathers for sale.

In the future, she would like to open a permanent store for clothing and shoe sales and to thereby increase her income. Carolina thus hopes to be able to afford good education for her children.

loans.use: Purchase of wax, cochineal, and leathers

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Ella is 29 years old. She finished her high school education and speaks Spanish and Aymara (indigenous language). She has two sons that are studying at school. Her dwellings are located in the 24 de junio (June 24th) barrio of Villa Chipana, Pilcuyo District in the province of El Collao

Elizabeth elaborates and sells breads since 10 years ago; a product that she sells every Sunday at the Ilave fair. She belongs to the "Lago Azul" (Blue Lake) Communal Bank. She started with a S/. 300.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency) loan that Ella invested in buying three sacks of flour. With this new loan of S/. 1,600.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency), which she promises to pay back in 3 months, Ella will buy three sacks of flour, one sack of sugar and wood. Being part of the Communal Bank taught her to be responsible with her payments. Her biggest hope is to be able to buy a house in Puno so her children can continue to study an also she dreams of having a great bakery.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Ella tiene 29 años de edad, culminó su estudio secundario, habla el idioma castellano y aymará, es conviviente, tiene dos hijos varones que están estudiando en la escuela. Su domicilio queda en el barrio 24 de junio de Villa Chipana, del Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia de El Collao. Elizabeth se dedica a la elaboración y venta de panes desde hace diez años producto que lo vende todos los domingos en la feria de Ilave. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Lago Azul” inicio con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra de tres sacos de harina. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,600.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 3 meses, compró tres sacos de harina, un saco de azúcar y leña. Estando en el banco Comunal aprendió a ser responsable en sus pagos. El gran anhelo que tiene es comprar una casa en Puno, para que sus hijos puedan seguir estudiando y tener un a gran panadería.

loans.use: Buying goods at wholesale(flour, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Paulina, Juliana And Maria Group

texts.en:
Paulina, Juliana and María belong to the Chiara Village Bank. Chiara is the town where they live, located an hour from Ayacucho. All three of them earn income farming cereals and tubers and selling other food items.

Paulina is 39 years old, married, and has 4 children. She earns income selling meat. Paulina purchases animals from the local communities, raises them and then sells them. In addition, she also sells traditional clothing. Juliana is 52 years old, married, and has 7 children. She raises bovines and produces cheese that she then sells to middlemen. María is 37, married, and has 4 children. María and her daughter weave pullovers and sell them to people living in the local district. Additionally, she also sells cheese.

Paulina, Juliana and María currently need a loan to buy goats, pigs, cows, wool, and cheese for sale.

They all dream about improving their households and about acquiring more farm animals to improve their businesses.

loans.use: Purchase of goats, pigs, cows, wool, and cheese for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.es:
Eusebia is 55 years old and was not able to get an education. She is married and has six children who are independent. She lives in the Miraflores Barrio of the Santa Rosa Village, Yunguyo District. She dedicates herself to sell cows and pigs which she buys and sells at the fairs of Yunguyo. She buys them to fatten them and after two months she sells them. She has started this activity at a young age. She belongs to the "Tupac Amaru" Communal Bank. At the beginning, she obtained a S/. 300.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency) loan that allowed her to buy four sheep. With this new loan of S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency), whcih she wil pay back in 4 months, Eusebia will be able to buy a bull to fatten, which she will sell after. By belonging to the Communal Bank, she has learned to make her loan payments on-time. The loan helped her and taught her to work and be able to prosper. Her big dream is that her children continue to study and be professionals

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Eusebia tiene 55 no logro estudiar, es casada y tiene seis hijos, quienes ya son independientes, vive en el barrio Miraflores de Villa Santa Rosa del Distrito de Yunguyo. Ella se dedica a la venta de vacas y chancho que los compra y vende en las ferias de Yunguyo, lo compra para engorde después de dos meses los vende, actividad a la que se dedica desde muy joven. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” a un inicio tuvo un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que compró cuatro ovejas. Con este crédito de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, compró un torete para engorde, el cual después será vendido. Perteneciendo al Banco Comunal aprendió a ser puntual en sus pagos. El crédito que se le dio le enseño a trabajar y salir adelante. El gran sueño que tiene es que sus hijos sigan estudiando y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buying cattle (bull).

loans.name: Amalia, Rosa And Fortunata Group

texts.en:
Amalia, Rosa and Fortunata belong to the Chiara Village Bank. Chiara is the town where they live, located an hour away from Ayacucho. All three of the women earn income farming cereals and tubers.

Amalia is 22 years old, married, and has two children. She owns a store where she sells groceries, vegetables, fruit, and clothes. The store is housed in a rented stand next to the district park. In addition to running the store, Amalia also raises animals, such as pigs and Guinea pigs that she sells at district fairs.

Rosa is 31, married, and has three children. She sells “salchipollo” (a dish consisting of chicken and french fries) from a cart in front of her house. Additionally, Rosa, like Amalia, raises animals.

Fortunata is 52, married, and has six children. She raises animals, such as bovines and goats, that she sells at district fairs.

Amalia, Rosa and Fortunata currently need a loan with a total value of US$800 to be able to buy children’s wear, oil, rice, sugar, chicken, and various items needed for farming.

They all dream about improving their families’ standard of living and being able to afford good education for their children.

loans.use: Purchase of children’s wear, oil, rice, sugar, chicken, and farm supplies

loans.name: Evarista

texts.es:
Evarista is 56 years old. She couldn't get an education because her parents wanted her to learn how to cook and do the house chores. She is married with 11 children, 7 of them are independent and the other 4 are with her. Her dwellings are located in the Miraflores Barrio, Santa Rosa Village, Yunguyo district

She dedicates herself to buy and sell cows, pigs, and sheep, an activity that she has been doing since young. She sells them at the Yunguyo market. She belongs to the "Tupac Amaru" Communal Bank where she started with a S/. 300.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency) loan that enable her to buy three piglets. With this new loan of S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency), which she promises to pay back in 4 months, Evarista will buy a pair of bulls to be fatten and sell them afterwards

She considers that the loans are a great help for her family and she has learned to be responsible and on-time with her payments. Her big dream is that her children continue to study, that they have a good job, and be able to get more cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Evarista tiene 56 años D. edad, no pudo estudiar por que sus padres le decían que tenia que aprender a cocinar y hacer los que aceres D. la casa, es casada tiene once hijos, siete D. ellos independientes y cuatro D. ellos esta a su lado. Su domicilio esta ubicado en el Barrio Miraflores D. Villa Santa Rosa Distrito D. Yunguyo. Se dedica a la actividad compra y ventas D. vacas, chanchos y ovejas, actividad a la que se dedica desD. muy joven, los venD. en los mercados D. Yunguyo. Ella pertenece al Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” donD. inicio con un crédito D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que compró tres chanchitos. Con este crédito D. S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, compró un par D. toros, que lo compro para engorD. los mismos que serán vendidos. Considera que estos créditos son una gran ayuda para su familia y aprendió a ser puntual en sus pagos. El gran sueño que ella tiene es que sus hijos sigan estudiando y tengan un buen trabajo y poder adquirir mas ganado.

loans.use: Buying cattle (bulls).

loans.name: Maria Rocio

texts.en:
María is 33 years old, married, and has a 9-year-old daughter. She belongs to the Solución Village Bank and has taken out a loan already once before. María works in the Magdalena market where she makes juices. She and her husband together own a car which they use to transport harvest during the sweet potato harvest season. María purchases potatoes from the producers and sells them in Nazca. In turn, in Nazca she buys “guano” (turkey excrements) to then sell it to the Ayacucho farmers.

María currently needs a loan of US$1,075 to repair the car that she and her husband use for their business. In the future, she hopes to be able to buy a new car, add more floors to her house, and open a hotel to ensure financial stability in old age.

loans.use: Repair of a car for business purposes

loans.name: Faustina

texts.es:
Faustina is 64 years of age. She completed her studies through the second year of secondary school. She is married and has seven children; three study, one works, the others are partnered.

She is dedicated to the sale of lunches; an activity that she has carried out every day of the week for 40 years in the District of Pilcuyo. Her residence is located in the neighborhood called “17th of September”, which is in Villa Chipana in the District of Pilcuyo, Province of El Collao.

She belongs to the "Blue Lake" Communal bank. She started with a loan of 300 new soles. With that she bought two bags of rice and a sack of noodles. With this loan of 1000 new soles, which will be repaid in 3 payments, she will buy a bag of rice, a sack of noodles, five liters of oil, potatoes and vegetables.

The loan helped her to improve her economic income and to be punctual in her payments.

Her great dream is to have a house in Puno, that her children continue studying and that they have a good job.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Faustina tiene 64 años de edad, estudio hasta segundo año de secundaria, es casada tiene siete hijos, tres estudian, uno trabaja, los demás tiene sus parejas.

Se dedica a la venta de Almuerzos, actividad que realiza todos los días de la semana, desde hace ya 40 años, en el Distrito de Pilcuyo. Su domicilio esta ubicado barrio 17 de Septiembre, esto en Villa Chipana Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia de El Collao.

Pertenece al banco Comunal “Lago Azul” inicio con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con el que compro dos sacos de arroz, una bolsa de fideos. Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en 3 cuotas, compró un saco de arroz, una bolsa de fideo, cinco litros de aceite, papa y verduras.

El crédito le ayudó ha mejorar su ingreso económico y a ser puntual en sus pagos.

El gran sueño que tiene es tener una casa en Puno, que sus hijos sigan estudiando y tengan un buen trabajo.

loans.use: To buy supplies to make lunches for sale, such as rice, noodles, oil, potatoes and vegetables.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Manuela Ramos / CrediMUJER - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Genara

texts.es:
Genara is 53 years old. She wasn't able to get an education but speaks Aymara (indigenous language) and understands Spanish. She is married and has six children which some of them are studying and others are married. Her home is located in the Miraflores Barrio which is in the Santa Rosa Village, Yunguyo district.

She dedicates herself to buy and sell cattle, pigs, and sheep which she gets at the Chacachaca and Yunguyo fairs. She belongs to the "Tupac Amaru" Communal Bank. She got an initial loan of S/. 300.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency) which she used to buy 2 sheep and a pig.

With this new loan of S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles (Peruvian currency), which she promises to pay back in 4 payments, Genara will buy a bull, which she will fatten and sell it after. Being part of the Communal Bank helped her to learn to be responsible and on-time with her payments. Her greatest wish is that her children continue to study and be able to buy a house in Puno

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

 Genara tiene 53 años de edad, no logro estudiar , habla el idioma aymará y entiende castellano, es casada y tiene seis hijos de los cuales todos estudian y los demás son casados. Su casa queda ubicada en el Barrio Miraflores esto queda en Villa Santa Rosa, distrito de Yunguyo. Ella se dedica a la compra y venta de vacas, chanchos, ovejas que son adquiridas en las ferias de Chacachaca y Yunguyo. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” tuvo un crédito inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que compró dos ovejas y un chancho. Con este crédito de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, compró un torete, que lo engordara y después lo venderá. Estando en el e Banco Comunal aprendió a ser solidaria y puntual en los pagos. El gran anhelo que ella tiene es que sus s hijos sigan estudiando y poderse comprar una casa en Puno.

loans.use: Buying cattle(bull).

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria is 45 years old. She was able to complete her elementary education. She speaks Spanish and Aymara (indigenous language) and is married to Don Lucio Yupanqui Condori. They have three children that are students; one of them studies in Arequipa and two in Yunguyo. She lives in Villa Queñuani, Yunguyo Duistrict.

Beforehand, she used to sell clothes which she will also took to Tacna and Arequipa. Since young she has been dedicated also to sell potato starch, potatoes, and quinoa which she actually does athe markets of Tacna and Arequipa

She belongs to the "Vista Alegre" Communal Bank and at the beginning she obtained a S/. 300.00 nuevos soles(Peruvian currency) loan which she invested in buying sheep. With the new loan of S/. 1,500.00 (Peruvian currency), which she promises to pay back in 4 payments, she will buy potato starch, potatoes, and quinoa in larger quantities.

Gregoria has also learned to be responsible with ther payments. Her biggest wish is to be able to buy a house in Arequipa and another one in Yunguyo, give a good education to her children and lately be able to buy a car.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Gregoria tiene 45 años de edad, logro estudiar primaria completa, habla castellano y aymará, es casada con don Lucio Yupanqui Condori, con quien tiene tres hijos, de los cuales los tres estudian, uno en Arequipa, dos en Yunguyo, ella vive en Villa Queñuani, Distrito de Yunguyo. Antes se dedicaba a la venta de ropa, que también llevaba hacia Tacna y Arequipa, actualmente, ella se dedica a la venta de chuño, papa, quinua, oca, que lo vende en mercados de Tacna y Arequipa inicio el negocio desde muy joven. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Vista Alegre” a un inicio tuvo un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles que lo invirtió en la compra de ovejas. Con este crédito de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, compró chuño, papa y quinua en mayores cantidades. Aprendió a ser responsable en sus pagos. El gran anhelo que ella tiene es, comprar una casa en Arequipa y Yunguyo, darles una buena educación a sus hijos, posteriormente comprarse un volvo.

loans.use: Buying tubers and cereal.

loans.name: Tauleva

texts.en:
Tauleva T., 33, is married with 7 children and lives at Safaatoa Uta, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas, which she sells to the villagers and the general public 3 days per week.

Tauleva has a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Tauleva’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase chemicals and pesticides for her crops.

loans.use: To buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana T., 46, is married with 5 children and lives in Fusi Safata, Samoa. She has been growing taro for 4 years and selling it to the public and villagers 2 days per week. Her husband helps her on her plantation and also runs a taxi.

This will be Susana's first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 700 Tala (US$291). SPBD loans are Susana’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used to purchase agricultural chemicals and to repair Susana's house.

loans.use: To purchase agricultural chemicals

loans.name: Temukisa

texts.en:
Temukisa T., 40, is married with 2 children and lives in Safaaoa Uta, Samoa. She has been growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas for two years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

Temukisa has a previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Temukisa’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase agricultural chemicals and pesticides.

loans.use: To buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina S., 19, is married with one child and lives in Safaatoa Tai, Samoa. She has 3 years of experience growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas, which she sells to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

Christina has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (US$62). SPBD loans are Christina’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use this loan to purchase agricultural chemical and pesticides.

loans.use: To buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides

loans.name: Meleseke

texts.en:
Meleseke T., 47, is married with four children and lives in Matafaa, Samoa. She has been growing giant taro (taro taamu) and bananas for three years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

Meleseke has a previous loan with SPBD and will use this loan to purchase agricultural chemicals and pesticides. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~$62US). SPBD loans are Meleseke’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Meleseke would like to buy agricultural chemicals and pesticides for her taro and banana crops.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina I., 55, is married with 7 children and lives at Luatuanuu, Samoa. She has 2 years of experience in the pig farm business. She sells to the villagers and general public 5 days per week.

Rosalina has had 2 previous loans with SPBD. She will use this loan to purchase fencing and feed for her pigs. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (US$83). SPBD loans are Rosalina’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy fencing and pig feed

loans.name: Fipe

texts.en:
Fipe I., 23, is widowed and lives in Vaitele, Upolu Island, Samoa. She has 3 years of experience in the taxi business, which she operates 6 days per week.

Fipe has a previous loan with SPBD. She will use this loan to repair her taxi. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (US$208). SPBD loans are Fipe’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase Use to repair the taxi

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en:
Tamara M., 58, is married with 5 children and lives at Nuusuatia, Samoa. She and her husband have been growing taro for 3 years. She sells her crop to the villagers and the general public 2 days per week.

This is Tamara's first loan with SPBD, which she will use to purchase equipment for her taro plantation. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (US$208). SPBD loans are Tamara’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase to fund chemicals,weedkiller,knife,empty gallon.

loans.name: Sinaoletavai

texts.en:
Sinaletavai T., 55, is married with 8 children and she lives at Faleasui, Samoa. She and her husband have 3 year(s) of experience in the plantation business. She sells her crop to the village community and and the general public 3 days per week.

Sinaletavai has 2 previous loans with SPBD. She will use this loan to buy the materials needed to repair her house. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (US$166). SPBD loans are Sinaletavai’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: For house repairs

loans.name: Faavevela

texts.en:
Faavevela F. is a 35-year-old married woman with 5 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fishing business, though her husband (a fisherman) does the majority of the fishing. In practice, she sells their fish to the village people and to the public at large 3 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

This is the first loan she has requested via SPBD. As a matter of fact, SPBD loans are Faavevela’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. The loans proceeds would be used to finance their fishing operations; more specifically, the proceeds would be used to finance the purchase of equipment, including a canoe, spears, and a freezer.

loans.use: To expand and improve her fishing operations by purchasing equipment (e.g., a canoe, spears, and a freezer).

loans.name: Fereni

texts.en:
Fereni M. is a 41-year-old married woman with 11 children. She has 2 years of experience in the crafts/mowing contract business, and her husband helps run and operate the business as the manager. In practice, she sells their crafts to the village community and to the public at large 5 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 520 Tala ($216 USD).

This is the first loan she has requested via SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Fereni’s only access to capital because she has never able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. The loan proceeds will primarily be used to repair her family's house, but also to pay for her kids' school fees.

loans.use: To repair her family's house and to cover her kids' fees for school

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa F. is a 30-year-old married woman with 3 children. She has 1 year of experience in the farming/vegetable garden business, though her husband does the majority of the actual farming, and she sells their crops to the public at large (as well as to hotels and restaurants) 4 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

This is the first loan that she has sought via SPBD. As a matter of fact, SPBD loans are Elisa’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. With the loan proceeds, she would like to start her vegetable garden by purchasing seeds, chemicals, and equipment (e.g., knives, weedkillers, and sharpeners).

loans.use: To start her vegetable garden by purchasing seeds, chemicals, and various pieces of equipment (e.g., knives, weedkillers, and sharpeners)

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora N. is a 44-year-old married woman with 5 children. Her husband works at Ott Transport to help support the family from a financial standpoint. She recently started a pancake business, and she is selling her food to the village community and school children 5 days per week. Typically, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 300 Tala ($125 USD).

This is the first loan she has requested via SPBD. In truth, SPBD loans are Nora’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. With the loan proceeds, she is hoping to expand and improve her business by purchasing various inputs (e.g., flour and oil) and equipment (e.g., frying pans and gas cookers).

loans.use: To ramp up her business' operations by purchasing raw materials (flour and oil) and equipment (frying pans and gas cookers)

loans.name: Faaolataga

texts.en:
Faaolataga S. is a 26-year-old married woman with 3 children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation/farming business, and she sells her crops to the public at large and to the village people 3 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

She has received 2 previous loans from SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Faaolataga’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. She would like to use a portion of the loan proceeds to repair her family's house, while the remaining loan proceeds would be used to expand and improve her farming operations by purchasing additional equipment.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional equipment and to repair her family's house

loans.name: Suliveta

texts.en:
Suliveta S. is a 43-year-old married woman with 7 children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation/farming business, and, with her husband's help, she sells her goods to the village people and to the public at large 4 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

She has received 2 previous loans from SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Suliveta’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with any of the traditional banks. A portion of the loan proceeds will be used to pay for her kids' school fees, while the remaining loan proceeds will be used to expand and improve her business by purchasing more equipment.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional equipment

loans.name: Voeurn

texts.en: Mr. Voeurn V. is a motorcycle taxi driver; his wife raises pigs. They live in Trapeang Thnal Village, Siem Reap Province. Mr. V. drives his motorcycle taxi around Siem Reap City and he makes about $4 per day. Because of the competitive market,  he tries to retain and increase his customer base. Now he is asking for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle to attract customers. He plans to use the remainder of the loan to purchase more pigs for his wife to raise.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle to attract customers

loans.name: Thi Huong

texts.vi:
Mrs. H. Thi Huong (ID number: 020021), is 26 years old. She wants to borrow 125 USD to buy fertilizer. She and her husband are very hard-working. Besides working on the rice field, they also are hired building workers. With an income of 6-7 USD/day, it is very convenient for them to repay weekly. They have one child who is still going to school.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Hoàng Thị Hường (MS: 020021), năm nay 26 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND mua lân đạm phục vụ nông nghiệp. Anh chị rất chịu khó, ngoài làm ruộng anh chị còn đi làm phụ xây, đổ bê tông đường làng ngõ xóm. Với mức thu nhập 110.000 VND/ngày sẽ giúp anh chị tiết kiệm tốt qua hình thức trả góp hàng tuần. Anh chị có một con nhỏ đang đi học.

loans.use: buy fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chuacante I Group

texts.en:
The women from the mujeres Chuacante group live in a popular tourist destination, San Pedro La Laguna, Lake Atitlan. They enjoy their community and are proud to have lived in it since childhood. Amongst the highlights of living in their town is the fact that they all own land there and enjoy a healthy church life and festive season, such as the town fair coming up in early June. The microcredit group that they are part of has brought them closer to each other through “unity and love amongst us,” as Norma G. described her experience.

When at home or in the workplace, these women, who are mostly mothers, dedicate their lives to weaving. Some are bead-workers and others are dedicated to selling fruit and vegetables. The weavers make traditional clothing such as colorful belts, aprons and tops (guipiles) and the bead-workers make bead belts and bracelets. They sell this merchandise to intermediaries who take it all over the region and re-sell it to stores, tourists and shoppers.

Norma G. began her business a few years ago and took out very small loans at high interest. Recently, she has switched over to loans of virtually no interest, which are generously provided online. She can now confidently take out large loans (and growing) of 340 USD and with it help pay the wages of her 6 employees who work with her to produce many more products than before, and sell them for cheaper, while still making a profit.

When asked about how their business was going, they complained about the rainy season and the drop in sales during this time of the year. They said that this lull in sales didn’t mean less work, but a whole other load to be taken care of. The credit that they receive from microlenders goes towards more cloth and string, which they can buy by bulk and get a cheaper deal. At the same time, they can invest in their business to produce better and more products. Secundina E. said that she “could see a difference” from the time she began to take out loans. She explained that she could now buy more, for less money, and realize larger profits.

The hard work, combined with the loans, allows them to successfully send their children to public school, and accomplish what Josefa B. described as one of her largest dreams: to create a successful business and make it grow to the point where loans are no longer needed, and financial self-sustainability of the family and business are reached and maintained.

loans.use: Purchase of materials such as thread, cloth,  dyes, weaving materials, bulk fruits and vegetables, beads

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Xuan

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Xuan (ID number: 020022), is 37 years old. She wants to borrow 125 USD to breed pigs. She is very hard-working. Besides working on the rice field, Mrs. Xuan and her husband also does business on waste metals to increase the income. Her husband is also a hired-worker to make bricks. With the income of 6-7 USD/day, repaying gradually is very convenient for her. She has 4 children who are still going to school.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nghiêm Thị Xuân (MS: 020022), năm nay 37 tuổi. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND để chăn nuôi lợn, phục vụ nông nghiệp. Chị rất chịu khó ngoài làm ruộng anh chị còn tranh thủ đi chợ sắt để có thu nhập hàng ngày. Còn chồng chị đi làm gạch ngói. Với thu nhập hàng ngày 100.000 VND cũng giúp anh chị tiết kiệm qua hình thức trả góp và phục vụ cho gia đình. Anh chị có 4 con hiên còn đang đi học.

loans.use: breed pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for SEDA - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chuacante Ii Group

texts.en:
The women from the Mujeres Chuacante II community are proud to live in a closely knit community where almost everyone knows everyone. They are happy to work in their group since they help each other by reminding of payment and meeting dates. They are happy to live in San Pedro and to have businesses there.

These women are dedicated to weaving microenterprises. They weave local vestige items such as guipils and cortes (pictured in group photo)and sell them to a local consumer market in San Pedro and Santiago. Sometimes they set up their own locals or stands at the town markets that meet once a week; if not, they sell to intermediaries who then distribute their products to the region’s towns.

Magdalena A. described her process as a cycle, where she invests in materials such as thread dyes and machinery, producing more finished items for less. She then sells them for larger profits, and takes the extra profits for living, while reinvesting the remainder. In this manner she hopes to nurture her business to reach a level where profits are large enough to perpetuate the cycle on its own without the need of loans, and of course, with a much more comfortable living standard for her, her husband and her children. Her children all attend school and she hopes to be able to continue to send them to school without interruption.

They expressed contentment with the help that the loans have brought their businesses, yet are frustrated by the slump in sales caused by the rainy season and the lull caused by the global economy. Nevertheless, the vast majority of these San Pedro women are content with the rate of growth that they have achieved with their businesses and that that they expect to achieve with the continual help of these essential loans.

The general consensus was that this money would go towards more base materials such as thread, dyes and weaving equipment. They need the loan more than ever due to the slump in profits. With the extra capital, they will hopefully be able to continue a comfortable life, produce the same amounts of items (guipils generally take about two weeks to make and cortes take about 3, according to Jesus C.) despite their lows in sales. There was no complaints about market oversaturation and harsh competition, as they mostly enjoy of sales to intermediaries who find the best markets, or other towns which lack weavers of the same sort.

The majority of these business owners agreed that their main priority was raising healthy and happy children who can go to school full time, without having to help the family with work. They were proud to tell me that all of their children go to school (they are all mothers except two.) Apart from children, they look to maintain a balance between dependence on their husbands and making a share of the profits, according to Gloria C., to prove themselves for their own satisfaction, their husbands and larger family.

Gloria and others look forward to the day that the hard work of profit reinvestment will lead them to a large, healthy business which is independent and functions with a smooth cycle, no longer in need of loans for their growth and profits. The profits, although simply an economic term to them, are synonymous with a future happy and prosperous family life and children who go on to beat most of the troubles that their parents are currently battling to go beyond.

loans.use: Purchase of thread, dyes, weaving equipment by bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Friendship Bridge - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sinatala

texts.en:

She has 2 years of experience in the elei/printing business, and she sells her goods to the village people and business people 6 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 500 Tala ($208 USD).

She has received 1 previous loan from SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Sinatala’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. With the loan proceeds, she hopes to expand and improve her business by purchasing more equipment.

Because of the crops' high price in the market, she needs to expand her crop business to get more profit. Now she is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase fertilizer to use for her crops.

Accordingly, she is able to sell her goods to the village people and business people 5 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

She is hoping to use a portion of the loan proceeds to repair her house, while the remaining proceeds will be used for general business purposes (e.g., to buy goods for the store).

loans.name: Tiki

Tiki P. is a 40-year-old married woman with 2 children. She has 3 years of experience in the farming/chicken business. Accordingly, she is able to sell her products to the publics 6 days per week. On average, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 300 Tala ($125 USD).

She has received 2 previous loans from SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Tiki’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from any of the traditional banks. With the loans proceeds, she is hoping to expand and improve her business by purchasing wire.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing wire

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris M. is a 33-year-old married woman with 3 children. She has 4 years of experience in the biscuits- and pie-making business. Accordingly, she sells her treats to the village people and to the public at large 6 days per week. Typically, her weekly net cash flow is approximately 400 Tala ($166 USD).

She has received 3 previous loans from SPBD. In fact, SPBD loans are Doris’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with any of the traditional banks. With the loan proceeds, she is hoping to expand and improve her business by buying additional ingredients.
