With this loan of S/.2000.00 ($725), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy two cows to be sold after the weight-gaining period. Thanks to the loans her family is able to move forward and she has learned to be responsible with her payments. Her dream is that her children continue studying and work.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

María tiene 55 años de edad, no pudo estudiar, habla solo aymará y entiende poco castellano, es casada y tiene seis hijos de los cuales cuatro son casados, dos que estudian. Su domicilio esta ubicada en el Barrio Central de Villa Santa Rosa, Distrito de Yunguyo. Se dedica a la compra y venta de vacas, ovejas y chanchos; comprando en las ferias de Huapaca, Chacachaca y Yunguyo, después de criarlas en el proceso de engorde también son vendidas en las mismas ferias, desde muy joven inicio con esta actividad. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” inicio con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que pudo comprar tres ovejas. Con este crédito de S/. 2000.00 nuevos soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará dos vacas que serán vendidas después del proceso de engorde. Gracias a los préstamos recibidos su familia puede seguir adelante, además aprendió a ser responsable en sus pagos. El anhelo que ella tiene es que sus hijos continúen estudiando y trabajen.

loans.use: Purchase of cows to be raised and sold.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.es:
Cecilia is 37 years old, completed high school, speaks Castilian and Aymara, is married and has a son in college. She lives in Barrio 24 of Junio, Pilcuyo district, El Collao province, Peru. She makes and sells bread (French bread, "tres esquinas," sarnita, and wheat bread), selling it in Llave and Pilcuyo. She has been baking bread since she was 15 years old.

She belongs to the Blue Lake Common Bank, and started with a $115 loan, with which she bought three bags flour. With this loan of $725, which will be repaid in 3 months, she will buy 10 bags of flour, 2 sacks of sugar, and 10 bags of salt. She says these credits have permitted her to increase her production and improve her income. She longs for her son to finish his studies and become a professional.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Cecilia tiene 37 años D. edad, logro estudiar secundaria completa, habla castellano y aymará, es casada, tiene un hijo que estudia en el Colegio, ella vive en el Barrio 24 D. Junio, del Distrito D. Pilcuyo, Provincia D. El Collao. La actividad a la que se dedica es elaboración y venta D. pan (marraqueta, tres esquinas, sarnita, D. trigo) vendiéndolo en Ilave y Pilcuyo actividad a la que se dedica desD. hace 15 años. Pertenece al banco Comunal “Lago Azul” inicio con un crédito D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con lo que compro tres sacos D. harina. Con este crédito D. S/. 2000.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 3 meses comprará 10 sacos D. harina, 2 sacos D. azúcar, 10 bolsitas D. sal. Dice que estos créditos le han permitido incrementar su producción y mejorar su ingreso económico. El gran anhelo que ella tiene es que su hijo siga estudiando, sea profesional.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of supplies and ingredients.

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es:
Dionicia is 33 years old, she completed primary school, speaks Aymara and Castilian, is married and has one baby boy. Her house is in the central neighborhood of Villa Santa Rosa, in the Yunguyo district, Peru. Dionicia buys and sells sheep and cattle and prepares them to be sold at fairs in Haupaca and Yunguyo. She has been raising and selling livestock since she was 4 years old.

She is a member of the "Tupac Amaru" Common Bank and started with a loan of $115, which she used to purchase sheep. With this loan of $200, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy a bull, which will later be sold to obtain higher earnings (the one she sold increased her capital, but it was not enough to purchase a new bull).

Being part of the Common Bank she has learned to be responsbile and punctual with her payments. Her great dream is to buy a house in Yunguyo and continue to work.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Dionicia tiene 33 años de edad, estudio primaria completa, habla aymará y castellano, es casada y tiene un bebe que es varón, su casa queda en Barrio Central de Villa Santa Rosa del Distrito de Yunguyo. Dionicia se dedica a la compra y venta de ovejas y vacas, para engorde, que después será vendido en las ferias de Huapaca y Yunguyo. Actividad a la que se dedica desde hace cuatro años. Pertenece la Banco Comunal “Túpac Amaru” inicio con un crédito de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles con lo que compro cuatro ovejas. Con este crédito de S/. 500.00, que será pagado en 4 meses, comprará un toro (para el que tuvo que aumentar dinero ya que no era suficiente), posteriormente será vendido y obtendrá mayor ganancia. Estando en el Banco Comunal aprendió a ser responsable y puntual en sus pagos. El gran sueño que ella tiene es comprar una casa en Yunguyo y continuar trabajando.

loans.use: Purchase of cattle (1 bull).

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa is 24 years old and completed 11 years of school. She lives with her only son, her husband died three years ago. She is one of the leaders of Mulla Contihueco, in the Juli district, Chucuito province, Puno region, Peru.

She sells embroidered tapestries and raises cattle. With the first loan she received from Las Kantutas Wilkauta Common Bank of $115 in 2007, she invested in 16 meters of material and 3 kilograms of colored wool yarn, allowing her to improve her income.

With this loan of $200, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 20 meters of material, 3 kilograms of wool, and other needed supplies. Overall, Rosa is very happy, especially since her improved earnings have increased her production. Her biggest dream is for her son to become a professional and that she can continue to capitalize in order to increase her production.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa tiene 24 años de edad, estudió hasta quinto de secundaria, vive con su único hijo, su esposo falleció hace tres años. Ella es una de las líderes del Centro Poblado de Mulla Contihueco, del distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, de la región Puno. Ella se dedica a la actividad económica de venta de bordado de bayeta y crianza de ganado. Con el primer crédito que recibió del Banco Comunal Las Kantutas Willkauta fue de S/. 300.00 Nuevos soles en el año 2007, lo cual invirtió en la compra de 16 metros de bayeta y 3 kilos de lana de color, esto permitió mejorar sus ingresos. Con este préstamo de S/.500.00 nuevos soles, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 20 metros de bayeta, 3 kilos de lana y otros. Por todo ello, ella esta muy feliz, ya que con la ganancia viene ampliando su producción. Su sueño más grande es que su hijo sea profesional y capitalizarse más para ampliar su producción.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of embroidery supplies.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.es:
Eulalia is 23 years old and completed high school. She is mother of one son and her vision is to have enough capital to constitute a business of Embroidering and bag making, and for her son to become a professional.

Eulalia is a partner of the Las Kantutas de Wilkauta Common Bank, of Mulla Contihueco, in the Juli disctrict, Chucuito Juli province, Puno region, Peru. She makes and sells bags and embroiders cloth tapestries, in addition to farming and cattle raising.

She learned to embroider when she was 12 years old, thanks to her mother. When she married her husband, Nilton Condori Quispe, she began making cloth bags, while embroidering tapestries. Since they lacked more capital to improve production they took out a loan for $115 from the Common Bank to buy 8 kilograms of red wool to make tapestries, and as a result increased their production and earnings.

With this loan of $375, which will be returned over a 4 month period, she will purchase 15 kilograms of wool in different colors, 25 meters of zippers, 10 bags of key-chains, and 300 buttons, with which she can increase her supplies.

She and her husband are very happy since they have improved their income from sales and fabrication of bags and embroidered tapestries, dealing directly to the local markets, such as Cusco and Puno.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Eulalia tiene 23 años de edad, estudió hasta superior no universitario, es madre de un hijo y su visión futura es tener más capital para constituir una Empresa de confección de Mochilas y Bordados, y sea profesional su hijo. La señora Eulalia, es socia del Banco Comunal Las Kantutas de Willkauta del Centro Poblado Mulla Contihueco, del distrito de Juli y provincia de Chucuito Juli de la región Puno. Se dedica a la confección mochilas y Bordado de Panoramas de Bayetilla y como actividad complementaria es agricultura y ganadería. Ella aprendió hacer Bordados desde los 12 años de edad gracias a su madre, cuando formaron el hogar con su esposo Nilton Condori Quispe, iniciaron con la Confección de Mochilas de Bayetilla y al mismo tiempo Bordados de Bayetilla. En ese entonces les faltó más capital para mayor producción y accedieron al préstamo de S/.300.00 nuevos del Banco Comunal para comprar 8 kilos de lana roja para confección de la bayeta, así logró incrementar su producción y ganancia. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles, que cancelará en un plazo de cuatro meses, comprará de 15 kilos de lana de diferentes colores, 25 metros de cierres, 10 bolsas de llavecitas y 300 botones, con ello logrará incrementar su material de producción para confección. Ella y su pareja se encuentran muy contentas ya que mejoró sus ingreso económicos por la venta de productos de confección de mochilas y Bordados, comercializando directamente a los mercados regionales como Cusco y Puno.

loans.use: Purchase of wool and materials in bulk.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
Antonia is 35 years old and completed primary school. She is the mother of 2 young children who are attending school. She is married to Eduardo C. Mamani, 34 years old, who works with her. She works primarily in rug embroidery in addition to raising a few pigs and sheep.

In order to increase her production of embroidered rugs, she decided to participate in the Las Kantuta Willkauta Common Bank, located in the town of Mulla Contihueco, district of Juli, Chucuito province, department of Puno, Peru.

Her first loan was for $115, with which she acquired 4 square meters of material and some rolls of colored wool yarn. With this loan of $200, which will be paid-in-full in 4 months, she will buy 2 kilograms of wool ,10 spools of colored wool yarn, and 20 meters of material.

Antonia is happy because her production is increasing daily and her income is much better than before. She has been successful in selling three to four panoramas weekly to travelers of Juli and Cusco, who pass by her home. Her greatest goal is to have enough capital to improve in embroidery, have a dairy business, and for her children to become professionals.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Antonia tiene 35 años de edad, su nivel de educación es primaria completa, es madre de 2 hijos menores de edad quienes están estudiando en la escuela y es casada con don Eduardo C. Mamani de 34 años de edad quien viene trabajando junto con ella. Actualmente, se dedica especialmente al Bordado de Bayeta y un poco de crianza animales menores como chanchos y ovejas. Para incrementar la producción de Bordados de Bayeta, decidió pertenecer al Banco Comunal Las Kantuta Willkauta, ubicado en el centro poblado Mulla Contihueco, del distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito y del departamento Puno. Su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, con ello adquirió cuatro metros cuadrados de Bayeta y unos cuantos ovillos de lanas de colores. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, el cual cancelará en 4 meses, comprará 2 kilos de lana, 20 metros de bayeta y 10 ovillos de lana. La señora Antonia se encuentra feliz por que su producción va incrementando cada día y sus ingresos económica esta mucho mejor que antes. Además logra vender semanalmente tres a cuatro panoramas a los intermediarios de Juli y Cusco, quienes van hasta su domicilio. Su mayor sueño es tener más capital para mejorar el Bordado, tener una empresa lechera y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: To buy wool in bulk.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
Elvira is 28 years old, completed only the first year of high school, is the mother of 3 children (2 boys, 1girl), who are attending primary school and depend on her and her husband. The family lives in the populated center of Mulla Contiheuco, Juli disctrict, Chucuito province and Puno region.

She and her husband embroider rugs, an activity Elvira began when she was 12 years old, thanks to her father who taught her. Her husband learned to embroider from her. Because they did not have enough money to purchase material, she decided to join the community bank, Las Kantuta of Wilkauta. After receiving a loan of $115, with which she acquired wool material for 3 panoramas and 3 kilograms of colored wool, she was able to increase her capital and her income.

With this loan of $450, which will be returned in 4 months, she will purchase 10 kilograms of colored wool and 60 meters of material. She is very happy, now that she is increasing her production of embroidery, as well as her capital to cover the costs of feeding and educating her children. Her biggest dream is to have enough capital to be an industrial Artisan and that her children be professionals.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Elvira tiene 28 años de edad, estudió hasta primero de secundaria es madre de 3 tres hijos (dos hijos y una hija), los cuales están cursando educación primaria que aun dependen de ella y de su esposo, viven en el Centro Poblado de Mulla Contihueco, del distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito y región de Puno. Ella y su esposo se dedican al Bordado de Bayetilla, esta actividad emprendió desde los 12 años de edad gracias a su padre quien la enseñó y su pareja aprendió de ella y por falta de dinero para comprar tela de Bayeta, ella decidió pertenecer al Banco Comunal Las Kantuta de Willkauta, con fin de acceder al préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con ella adquirió Bayeta de lanilla para 3 panoramas y tres kilos de lana de colores, con ello incremento su capital y ingreso económico. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200.00 nuevos soles, el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará 10 kilos de lanas de colores y 60 metros de bayeta. Ella esta muy contenta, ya que sigue incrementando su producción de Bordado y su capital para cubrir los gastos de alimentación y educación de sus hijos. Su sueño principal es tener mas capital para ser empresaria de artesanía y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Purchase of wool in bulk

loans.name: Armando Martin

texts.es:
Entrepreneur Armando Martin P. F.is 43 years old, is married, and has two children who study in the secondary level. Armando for 6 years has operated a woodworking shop where he constructs all types of furniture including chairs, tables, and playpens, among other products.

Mr. P. suffered an accident a few years ago in which he lost his right leg, necessitating that he use a prosthesis. Nonetheless, he has not been limited by the incident, and has been able to get ahead in his business and to support his family. Armando normally works only in his shop, but when there is great demand, he contracts other workers in order to be able to fulfill his work commitments.

Armando needs an electric sander to faciliatate his work as he currently does his sanding manually. He requires financing to buy an electric sander, which costs $250 US, and to buy 200 feet of wood as raw material, which costs $1.00 US per foot.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

El microempresario Armando Martin P. F.tiene 43 años de edad, es casado, tiene dos hijos los cuales estudian en nivel secundaria. El señor P. desde hace 6 años tiene un taller de ebanisteria en donde construye todo tipo de muebles tales como sillas, mesas, camas jugueteras entre otros productos.

El señor P. hace varios años sufrió un accidente en donde perdió su pierna derecha, lo cual le obliga a usar una prótesis. Sin embargo esto no ha sido una limitante y el microempresario P. a podido salir adelante con su taller y ser el sustento de su familia. Este microempresario trabaja normalmente solo en su taller pero cuando tiene mucha demanda contrata otros trabajadores para poder cumplir sus compromisos de trabajo.

Actualmente requiere una lijadora eléctrica que le permita agilizar su trabajo ya que el servicio de lijado lo hace a través de lijas manualmente. Por lo tanto requiere el financiamiento para comprar una lijadora eléctrica la cual cuesta US$ 250 y 200 pies de madera como materia prima la cual le cuesta US$ 1.00 cada pie.

loans.use: Purchase of an electric sander and 200 feet of wood. Para comprar una lijadora electrica y 200 pies de madera.

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 37.50 dólares

loans.name: Rithe

texts.en: Mr. Rithe D. is a villager in Kveth Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. He is a subsistence farmer and construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Sundany Khon, is employed in a garment factory. They now live with their parents and they would like to build a new house where they can live on their own. So Mr. Rithe D. decided to ask for a loan to be able to afford a new house. So far, Mr. Rithe D. obtained a loan to pay for his wedding ceremony. Mr. Rithe D. and his wife are shown in the picture.

loans.use: to build a house

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um N. is a fish-paste seller while her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. They both live in Kork Phnov Village, Siem Reap Province. She buys fish-paste from villagers in her area and resells it for a profit. They have five children, one of whom is married; the four others are in school.

N. makes about $10 per day while her husband earns about $5 per day driving his motorcycle taxi. Now N. is asking for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband to use instead of his old one so as to attract more customers. She can also use it to transport her fish-paste to sell. The loan will allow her to increase her family’s income using the motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for her husband

loans.name: Hana

texts.en:
Hana A., 41, is married with 5 children. She has 2 years of experience in the pancakes business. She sells to the villagers and local school children 6 days a week. She has received 5 previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

SPBD loans are Hana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. The loan will be used primarily to purchase ingredients needed for her food sales business. The remainder will be used to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients needed for her food (pancakes) business.

loans.name: Heam

texts.en:
Mr. Heam C. makes bamboo coops to sell from his house while his wife is a farmer. They have four children and live in Run Choeung Village, Siem Reap Province. All of their children are young and in school.

Because of the ever increasing cost of living, Heam C. needs to increase his income and he is now asking for a loan to purchase oxen and pigs to breed. He plans to use the remainder of the loan to purchase more bamboo to make coops to sell. The loan will allow him to expand his business and increase the family’s income as well as improving their living conditions. (The picture is one son of Mr. C. because C. and his wife were not available.)

loans.use: To purchase oxen and pigs to breed

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en: Mrs. Phorn Y., 32 years old, is a farmer who raises ducks while her husband is a rice wine maker. Mrs. Y. makes around $4.13 per day and her husband earns about $3.33 per day. They have four children, all of whom live at home in Daunley Village in Siem Reap Province. Her duck breeding business is expanding and Mrs. Y. would like to ask for a loan to purchase more ducks to breed. She would like to use the remainder of her loan to help her husband fix his wine making kiln.

loans.use: To purchase ducks and fix wine making kiln

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas D., 39, sells groceries from her house and earns around US$ 2.33 per day. Her husband, Mr. Hong My, is a farmer and grows crops. He earns around $1.60 per day. They have three children and live in Thnoltrong Village, Siem Reap Province. Two of their children help their father to farm and grow crops, and the other one is in school.

D. is seeking a loan in the amount of US$ 300 to purchase more grocery inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery inventory

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann H., 51, is a duck and pig raiser who earns around $5.16 per day. Her husband, Mr. Suy Chhay, earns combined around $2.33 per day farming and fishing. They live in Tropeang Prey Village, Siem Reap Province, and have three children, all of whom are young and attend school.

Because of ever increasing family expenses which they desire to reduce, H. is now seeking a loan of US$ 1,200 to purchase a motorcycle for her family to use. The loan will allow them to improve the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family to use

loans.name: Gulzamon

texts.en:
D. Gulzamon is 32 years old. She has been married for twelve years and has three children. Her husband is a taxi driver. Gulzamon and her husband are raising their children with love and trying to ensure their children have everything they may need. 

Gulzamon has been running her business for 10 years. She is selling fabric for national dresses. National dresses in Tajikistan are very popular and very important items in the dowry of any girl. Gulzamon has two trading places in the local market. Being very polite with the clients and having good taste, Gulzamon has her customers in each market. All the fabrics are supplied form the neighboring city of Dushanbe.

Gulzamon is trying to have a wide range of goods to able to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of clients with different income levels. Also, her children are growing and their expenses are raising concomitantly. Thus, Gulzamon wants to expand her business in order to meet all the needs of her dearest children. Gulzamon requests $1000 US to increase the range of the goods she sells. She would like to thank everyone who decides to support her, and she promises to repay the loan in 4 months' time.

loans.use: Purchasing of the new fabrics for increasing the range of goods.

loans.name: Farrukh

texts.en: E. Farrukh is 23 years old. He is married with an adorable kid. Farrukh has been farming since he was a young boy, and now he specializes in the cultivation of wheat and rice. He has worked the land since he was 17. When it is the season, Farrukh works in the field from early morning until late at night. Farrukh has a large and friendly family. They all try to help each other. His mother who helps him with the business was pictured on the photo as Farrukh by himself was absent that day. Now when the business is stable Farrukh believes that it shall be the main income for him in the future as his dearest children are growing up and their expenses are raising concomitantly. Today Farrukh requests 1000 Somoni ($300 US) for the term of 6 months. Farrukh is planning to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. He thanks everyone who supports him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Sirojidin

texts.en: E. Sirojidin is 28 years old. He is married with two children. He loves his children very much and doesall the best in order to make them happy and give them a good education. Sirojidin is running the farm. He has worked in agriculture for ten years, and in that time has gained much experience and a love for the land. His father and brothers help him with the business. He is growing wheat, rice, and different kinds of seasonal vegetables. The business is stable and generates the main source of income for the family. However, this business requires lots of work and capital. In the current season, Sirojidin wants to grow wheat, potatoes, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Thus, Sirojidin needs to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer, and he requests 1000 Somoni ($300 US) for the term of 6 months. Sirojidin thanks those who support him and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Khushmurot

texts.en: K. Khushmurot is 26 years old. He is married with three children. His wife is a housekeeper and takes care of their children. Khushmurot is a farmer. He has 3 years of experience, and he has been able to support his family by learning how to take care of and manage his crops in the short growing season. He is producing crops such as wheat, potatoes, onions, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Each year he is growing the yield sufficient for the family consumption and for selling. The business is the main source of income and generating the stable income at the same time requires considerable funding. Thus, now Khushmurot needs to purchase mineral fertilizer and seeds for planting. For this purpose he requests 3400 Somoni ($1000US) for the term of 12 months. Khushmurot would like to use this loan to buy supplies for the harvest and for improving production, and thus increase the quality of his yield along with his earnings at the time of sale. With your help, this will be possible. He thanks all those who support him and promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Mrs. Ou K., a widow,  is a farmer as well as selling traditional Cambodian cakes (Num Banhchhev). She has two children and one of her daughters is a vegetable seller who helps K. with repayments. They both live in Chreytbong Village, Siem Reap Province. Their incomes cannot support the family’s expenses sufficiently so K. needs to expand her business to increase their income. She is now asking for a loan to purchase a plot of farmland to expand her farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland to expand her farming business

loans.name: Thor

texts.en: Thor S., 58, is a widow who lives in Prey Veng with her one unmarried child. She works in her little grocery store, selling a wide variety of products, and typically makes US$5 each day. She has worked in the same little store for about eight years now and has seen her customer demand rise, so she would like to invest in  more products to add to her inventory. She has asked for a loan of US$500 to expand her inventory and to help her grocery store grow. Thor is also supported by her child who earns around US$5 each day, but this inventory expansion can really help to increase her daily income. She believes this investment will be a great opportunity for her and her family and looks forward to seeing the results of her loan.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Kurbongul

texts.en:
K. Kurbongul is a 60-year-old woman. She is married. She has two adult children and several wonderful grandchildren. Despite her ripe old age, her energy shines in her activities. Together with her husband, they have been involved in spare parts sales for household needs since 1999, at which time her entrepreneur son provided Kurbongul with startup funding. Gradually the business of Kurbongul expanded. Being hard working and polite by nature, she managed to build a clientele that is happy with the goods and services she provides. The income she derives allows her to provide for her personal needs as well as those of her family.

Today Kurbongul requests $900US for the term of 4 months. She is planning to spend the loan for purchasing spare parts to increase the range of goods. Kurbongul and her husband are counting on your help. She expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing of spare parts to increase the range of goods

loans.name: Chab

texts.en: Chab O., 36, sells a variety of grocery products out of her home in Prey Veng and typically makes US$2 each day. She has worked out of her home for the last four years and her husband, Phul Virak, drives a motortaxi in the city each day.  His revenue varies from week to week. They must support three children in their family and they would like to see their income increased. To increase their income they have thought about a business plan that would expand their current grocery store and increase the inventory to reach more customers. Chab O. has asked for a loan of US$300 to purchase more inventory.  She believes that this investment will help her business thrive in the future and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Increase grocery inventory

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em P., 48, raises and sells pigs out of her home in Prey Veng, typically making US$2.50 each day. Her husband, Chuon Reth, operates a motortaxi service at the local market and can usually earn US$3 each day. They have two children. One child is married and lives with their own family, while the other is a student. They have asked for a loan of US$1000 to expand Em P.'s pig business through the purchase of some piglets. They believe that this can be a great opportunity to see their income increased and their standard of living improved. The investment should become very profitable after a few short months and then they can use the profits to support their family and improve their living conditions. They are very appreciative of this loan and grateful for the opportunity that it will provide.

loans.use: Purchase piglets

loans.name: Leinati

texts.en:
Leinati T., 20, is married with 2 children. She has 2 years of experience in the elei printing business. Elei is a traditional way of printing textiles for shirts and dresses. Leinati sells her wares to the villagers and general public 5 days a week.

Leinati has received 2 previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD). SPBD loans are Leinati’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. This loan will be used to maintain her business by purchasing more materials for elei printing. Her husband works at Elaine Mart to help support the family.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed for elei printing.

loans.name: Malae

texts.en:
Malae V., 58, is married with 5 children and has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public 3 days a week. She has 3 previous loans with SPBD and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  

SPBD loans are Malae’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy items for her farming business, such as gromozone and chemicals. Some will also be used to pay for her childrens' school expenses and for home improvements. Her husband does the farming on the plantation.

loans.use: To buy items for her plantation business, such as gromozone and chemicals.

loans.name: Lisi

texts.en:
Lisi U., 50, is married with 4 children. She has 3 years of experience in the food business. She sells to the local school children 5 days a week. She has received 1 previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

SPBD loans are Lisi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. This loan will be used to purchase materials such as flour, tomato sauce and sausages for her food business.

loans.use: To purchase materials such as  flour, tomato sauce and sausages.

loans.name: Nina

texts.en:
Nina S., 35, is married with 5 children. She has 2 years of experience in the food and restaurant business. She operates the restaurant and sells food to the public 6 days a week. She has received 1 prior loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).

SPBD loans are Nina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. The loan will be used to organise the restaurant and purchase goods needed to run the restaurant . Her husband also helps out in running the business.

loans.use: To purchase goods and equipment for the restaurant.

loans.name: Nive

texts.en:
Nive L., 59, is married with 6 children. She has 3 years of experience in the elei printing business. She sells to the villagers and general public 5 days per week.

Nive has 3 previous loan(s) with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Nive’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. Her current loan will be used to pay for the costs of operating the elei printing business, including labour costs. Her husband is a farmer.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed for her elei (a traditional way of printing textiles for shirts and dresses) business.

loans.name: Mamele

texts.en:
Mamele F., 36, is married with 2 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fishing business. She sells to the villagers and general public 4 days per week. She has no previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Mamele’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. This loan will be used to finance fishing equipments. Her husband helps with all the fishing, which brings in income to support their family.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets ,spears, goggles and fishing rods

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana A., 30, is married with 5 children. She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the public and villagers 4 days per week.

Ana has received 3 previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Ana’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase weedkiller, gromozones, knives, sharpeners and chemicals for her plantation.

loans.use: To purchase weedkiller, gromozones, knives, sharpeners and chemicals needed for farming on her plantation.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria L., 42, is married with 2 children. She has many years of experience in the grocery store business. She sells groceries to the villagers and general public 6 days per week.

Maria has not borrowed from SPBD before. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. This loan will be used to fund items and products for her grocery store. Her husband works in the customs department..

loans.use: T purchase items and products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Danira Vaa

texts.en:
Danira Vaa P., 20, is married with 2 children. She has 2 year's experience in the vegetable farming business. She sells to the village people and 4 days per week.

Danira has 1 previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Danira’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. This loan will be used to buy fences, gromozones, fertilizers and vegetable seeds of different kinds. Any remaining money will be used to repair her house. Her husband who works in New Zealand has also helped in financing the family.

loans.use: To buy fences, gromozones, fertilizers and vegetable seeds of different kinds.

loans.name: Sii

texts.en: Sii E., 60, is married with 12 children.  She has 1 year of experience in the Pancakes business. She sells to the village people and public 5 days per week. This loan is Sii's first with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Sii’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan received through SPBD will be use to further expand the business.

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, frying pan (big one)

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy T., 29, is married with 3 children and has many years of experience in the taro/plantation business. She sells taro to village communities and her relatives 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

Dorothy has 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Dorothy’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. She will use part of her new loan to replace all tools and chemicals for her busness such as cromozone, sting chemicals, weedkiller sprayer, shovels, bushknives, spades, axes, wheelbarrows and also to support her children at school. Her husband helps with all the farming and has recruited the young men of the village to help out with their plantation.

loans.use: To replace all equipment for her plantation and to pay for new labor on the plantation

loans.name: Lauvale

texts.en: Lauvale P., 43, is married with three children. She has one year of experience in the Samoan pancake business. She sells these pancakes in her village five days per week. Her anticipated weekly net cash flow is 300 Tala (~120 USD). This is her first loan through SPBD; these loans are Lauvale’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar and other supplies for a Samoan pancake business.

loans.name: Agalelei

texts.en: Agalelei U., 22, is a young married woman with five years of experience in the BBQ business. She sells her BBQ in the village five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (~220 USD). This is her first loan through SPBD; these loans are Agalelei’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase all items, including meat and supplies, for her BBQ business.

loans.use: Purchase chicken, sausages, BBQ sauce, paper plates, and other supplies for a BBQ business.

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en: Matalena V., 36, is married with five children. She has three years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells her vegetables in the village five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala (~220 USD).  This is her first loan through SPBD; these loans are Matalena’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable farming business.

loans.name: Alieta

texts.en: Alieta P., 43, is married with five children. She has four years of experience in the handicrafts business. She sells her wares in the village four days each week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala (~187 USD). This is her first loan through SPBD; these loans are Alieta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan entirely for the purchase of handicrafts to resell.

loans.use: To purchase more handicrafts for resale.

loans.name: Iliganoa

texts.en: Iliganoa M., 42, is married with four children. She has many years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells in the village and at the public market three days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~100 USD). She has three previous loans with SPBD; these loans are Ileganoa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. She will spend the whole of her loan to replace equipment on her plantation, which she operates with financial support from her husband who sends money from American Samoa where he works.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of equipment (shovels, pesticides, knives) for a taro plantation.

loans.name: Tepa

texts.en: Tepa I., 48, is married with five children. She has many years of experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to friends, relatives and the village community during the peak season. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~140 USD). She has one previous loan with SPBD; these loans are Aiga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. The loan will assist her in operating her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of equipment (shovels, pesticides, knives) for a taro/banana business.

loans.name: Maave

texts.en: Maave M., 66, is married with eleven children. She has three years of experience in the popcorn and ice cake business. She sells to the people in the village four days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~100 USD). SPBD loans are Maave’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks. All of the loan will go towards supplies for her business.

loans.use: Puchase popcorn, popcorn bags, plastic cups, and other supplies for a popcorn and ice cake business.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay C. R., 25, has been grinding rice crops for the last four years and typically makes US$3 each day. She lives in Prey Veng with her husband, Nou Noeung, their two children, and her parents. Lay C. R. works together with her husband and they are seeking  ways to cut down on expenses and increase their daily income. They have noticed that  high gas prices have created an increased expense for them to transport their rice to the market to sell. They would like to purchase a new motorbike. They have asked for a loan of US$500 to make this investment. They believe that they will see their profits increased and their standard of living improved. They appreciate the opportunity that this loan will provide for their family and they are looking forward to the results.

Lay C. R. was not available at the time for a photograph, so her husband, Nou Noeung, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for business transportation

loans.name: Salote

texts.en: Salote S., 28, is married with three children. She has three years of experience in the taxi business. She works in the village community one day each week; she expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). She has had six previous loans through SPBD. SPBD loans are Salote’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks. She will use part of her loan to support her kids at school and improve their home; her husband is the general manager for their buisness and has the additional qualification of performing air conditioner repair.

loans.use: To purchase replacement equipment for her taxi business, mostly labor.

loans.name: Aiga

texts.en: Aiga C. Por Y., 35, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to friends, relatives and the village community three days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~120 USD). She has two previous loans with SPBD; these loans are Aiga’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. The loan will assist her in operating her business, which she operates with help from her husband, who farms the plantation and also recruits employees for the plantation.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of equipment (shovels, pesticides, knives) for her taro/banana business.

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Ma S., 30, is a young married woman looking to enter the Samoan pancake business. She plans to sell these pancakes in her village and to students at Primsry school five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be approximately 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Ma’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through the traditional banks. She plans to spend her loan to launch her business with support from her husband who works at the Water Authority department.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for a Samoan pancake business.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn T., 42, makes her own ice cream and then travels with her cart, selling  in a variety of locations and earning  about US$5 each day. She lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Sou T.. He works alongside his wife making the ice cream, but sells it in a different location. It is really a family business, for every  one of their five children sells ice cream as well and can make US$5 each day. Sorn T. has been thinking about new ways that she can help increase the income of her family, and she believes that venturing into a pig business could be very profitable. She has asked for a loan of US$700 to purchase some pigs to breed. The addition of pigs to the income of the family would allow them to diversify their sources of income and would help create more stability for the family. Sorn looks forward to the opportunities that this loan would provide her family and cannot wait to see the results of her investment.

loans.use: Purchase pigs to breed

loans.name: Katifa

texts.en: Katifa B., 49, is married with seven children. Katifa has many years of experience in the sewing business. She sells her wares in the village community five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD). SPBD loans are Katifa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. She plans to spend the loan on supplies for her business. Her husband works as a night auditor for Aggies Hotel and as the head coach for a rugby team; he plans to work part-time as a finanacial assistant for Katifa's business.

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine, materials, lavalava, threads, and other supplies for her sewing business.

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: Alicia S., 26, is married with three children. She has many years of experience in the printing design business. She sells her wares in the village five days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~100 USD). SPBD loans are Alicia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. She will use the loan to purchase supplies for her printing design business.

loans.use: Purchase paints, brushes, broom, cardboard for design, lavalava in different colours and other materials for her printing design business.

loans.name: Tauala Feagai

texts.en: Tauala Feagai, 55, is married with 11 children. She has many years of experience in the taro/banana business. She sells to friends, relatives and the village community three days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~120 USD). She has one previous loan(s) with SPBD; these loans are Tauala’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan through traditional banks. The loan will assist her in operating her business, which she operates with help from her husband.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of equipment (shovels, pesticides, knives) for her taro/banana business.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim V. S., 29, raises pigs in Siem Reap and typically makes US$5 each day in a business he has run for the last 3 years. His wife, Choo Sareth, takes care of their three children at home. They have been looking for ways to expand their business to increase their income. Inflation has been very high over the past year and gas prices have affected many people in Cambodia. Sim V. S. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike to use for his business transportation. He would like to have easy access to the local markets, in order that he may reach his customers effectively. Sim believes his income can greatly increase and his standard of living can be improved through this investment. He is grateful for the opportunity that this loan would provide to help support his family and he looks forward to the results.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for business transportation

loans.name: In

texts.en: In M., 64, is a widow who lives in Siem Reap with her son's family. She takes care of the house and the grandchildren, but she would like to help the family increase its daily income. She has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her son. She believes that if her son has a new motorbike he can operate his own taxi service, earning more income for the family. Inflation has been very difficult for many Cambodians over the last year and many people have been looking for ways to diversify their income and start new businesses. In M. believes that this investment will allow her family to increase its income and also create a better sense of stability. She wants to help out her son's family in any way she can and looks forward to seeing the results of this loan.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike to operate a taxi service

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mrs. Pen T., 49, is a farmer as well as raising pigs. She has been farming for nineteen years and she makes about $1.33 per day. Her husband is a bricklayer who earns about $2.16 per day. They live with their two children in Daunley Village, Siem Reap Province. Now T. is asking for a loan to purchase fertilizer for her rice crop. She will use the remainder of the loan money to purchase pigs to raise. The loan will allow her to improve the family’s income and living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her rice crop and pigs to raise

loans.name: Pisey

texts.en:
Mr. Pisey M. and his wife, Mrs. Channet Lao, are subsistence farmers in Tumnop Thmey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Aside from this business activity, Mr. Pisey M. is a firewood seller. He is 28 and the father of two children, both of whom are too young to work or be enrolled in school.

In order to improve his family's living conditions, Mr. Pisey M. now wants to start a rice mill business which can transform or husk rice for a profit. Mr. Pisey M. and his wife are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To start up a rice mill business

loans.name: Sab

texts.en: Sab S., 35, and her husband, Kuy Koeun, live in Siem Reap and have been working in the farm fields for the last eighteen years. They work the land together and they typically make US$5 a day combined after they sell their crops in the local food market. They have three children who all still live in the household. Inflation has made it a very difficult year economically for most Cambodians and the rural areas seem to be affected the most. Sab S. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase some cows to help her plow the farmland. The land must be plowed each year and this purchase will allow her to increase the quality and quantity of the crops she is able to grow. It is an investment that gives her an opportunity to better support her family. Sab looks forward to seeing the results of the loan.

loans.use: Purchase cows to help plow

loans.name: Soben

texts.en:
Mrs. Soben S. lives in Kveth in Kampong Chhnang Province. She and her husband, Mr. Chheun Kong, are rice farmers. Aside from this business activity, Mrs. Soben S. is a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding business has improved, Mrs. Soben S. wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Soben S. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets to raise.

Mrs. Soben S. is 48 and the mother of six children, one of whom is working in Naga Club, a famous gambling place in Phnom Penh. A second child migrated to work in Thailand while another one assists his parents in the rice fields. The remaining three are attending the local school.

Previously, Mrs. Soben S. obtained a loan from AMK to buy a cow for breeding. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise

loans.name: Chhoeum

texts.en: Chhoeum K., 42, makes wine and raises pigs with her husband, Kleng Phal in Siem Reap. They support their two children as well, one is a student and the other is a sculptor. They typically make US$5 each day together.  They have asked for a loan of US$350 to purchase more piglets to breed. The way that pigs are raised in Cambodia is that they are fed a wine that most pig breeders also make to help them sleep and become very large, very fast. So most pig breeders are also making wine and the family believes that their income can be increased through this investment. Chhoeum and her husband look forward to the opportunity to improve their standard of living and see the fruits of their investment.

loans.use: Purchase more piglets to breed

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun K., 35, takes care of her household, and lives in Siem Reap with her husband, Lenn Theat, and one of her children. Her husband travels around the community and sells firewood to a variety of businesses, making US$5 each day. Her child helps her husband with his firewood business, but they need to purchase two cows and a cart to aid with the transportation. Their current transportation is unreliable and they need to be able to depend on the business to support their family. Khun K. has asked CREDIT for a loan of US$700 to purchase these items for her husband, to help support her family. She believes that his investment can increase her daily income and improve her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase two cows and a cart for business transportation

loans.name: Phov

texts.en:
Phov P., 49, is a farmer who lives in Siem Reap with his wife Dum Mey and their four children. He has been working out in his fields as a farmer for the last ten years and his wife works with him, as they also raise pigs for about US$5 each day. They support their children who are still a part of the household and they have asked for a loan of US$500 to purchase feed for their pigs. They have struggled through some difficult economic times, like much of Cambodia has, and they would like to expand their pig breeding business to better serve their customers. They appreciate the opportunities that this loan provides and look forward to the results.

Phov P. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so his wife, Dum Mey, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase feed for pigs

loans.name: La

texts.en:
Mr. La U., 27, and his wife, Mrs. Putheavy Ream, 26, who live in a Phnom Penh suburb, were married in 1997 and have two children, one son and one daughter, both of whom are in school.

Mr. La has been a motor taxi driver for a half year. Before starting this business, he worked in a restaurant for many years, while Mrs. Putheavy has been a garment factory worker for three years. The Tuk Tuk (a motorized rickshaw) is now more popular than the motorcycle taxi in Phnom Penh City, so Mr. La is requesting a loan of $1000 to bU. a trailer in order to offer tuk tuk transportation in his business.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer for his motor taxi.

loans.name: Chhup

texts.en: Chhup P., 52, lives in Siem Reap with three of her children. She goes out to her field each day and grows vegetables and rice to sell in the local food market. Typically she makes US$1.50 each day, but she is also supported by her son who works in construction. The other two children are students in the local schools and are dependent upon the family's income. Inflation has made it difficult for many Cambodians to support their families this past year, and many are forced to look for ways to increase their income. Chhup P. has asked for a loan of US$1200 to purchase a cow to help her plow her farmland. The land needs to be plowed each year, and this investment can help cut down on some expenses. She looks forward to the opportunities that this loan provides and looks forward to the results.

loans.use: Purchase cow to help plow

loans.name: Vanna's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna N. (shown in the picture on the right with her group members) was selected to be a group leader for a loan from Maxima. The group members all live on an island on the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh:

1-Mrs. Vanna N., 34, and her husband, Mr. Mov Say, were married in 1992 and have three children, one son and two daughters, all of whom are in local school. Vanna has been a silk weaver since she was 14 years old, a skill she learned from her aunt, while Mr. Mov has practiced the trade for 16 years. Now Vanna is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase silk material for weaving.

2-Mrs. Sinkhoeun S., 33, and her husband, Mr. Rin Bophea, were married in 1993 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in local school. Sinkhoeun has been a silk weaver since she was 12 years old, a skill she learned from her parents, while Mr. Rin is a construction worker. Sinkhoeun is requesting a loan in the amount of $150 to purchase silk material for weaving.

3-Miss Channy C., 32, is single and lives with her elderly father. She has been a silk weaver since she was 14 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $150 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophy L., 45, and her husband, Mr. Phin Bo, 41, who live on an island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1987 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of their children have full time employment in Phnom Penh, and the third attends the local school.

Sophy has been a silk weaver for 22 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. Phin is a motor taxi driver. Sophy is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase silk material to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel A. sells drinks. He is married, but his wife's income from her barbershop does not provide enough additional support for Daniel and his three children. He has a popular business, and is asking for additional capital to expand and increase his profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence Y. sells rice, oil, and other foodstuffs. She is married, but her husband's teaching income is not sufficient for Florence and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she seeks additional capital to expand her business and increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati Y. sells maize, gari (fried cassava dough), ground nuts, beans, and other foods. She a single mother and needs greater income to support herself and her three children. There is a high demand for her goods, and so she would like additional capital to expand her business and increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Kunthea

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthea T., 38, and her husband, Mr. Lonh Sum, 47, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh, have been married for 20 years and have five daughters. Two of them are in school and two others are weavers.

Kunthea has been a silk weaver for 10 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who T. resells them in Phnom Penh. Lonh has been a wooden house builder for 30 years. Now Kunthea is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana M. sells sandals, second-hand clothing, and onions. She is single and her income does not provide enough support for Diana and her five children. Her goods are in high demand, so she is asking for additional capital to expand her business and increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Rosetta

texts.en: Rosetta E. sells sugar, tea, tomatoes, and other groceries. She is married and has one child. Her husband drives a taxi, but his income is not enough for full family support. Fortunately, demand for her goods is high, and so she is seeking additional capital to expand her business and increase her profits.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. Mao H., 61, and his wife were married in 1981 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. Two of their children are fishermen, one raises cows, one is a garment factory worker, and the last one is in school. The family lives along National Road Number Five about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mr. Mao has been in the business of selling cows for over 10 years. He buys them from villagers and from the nearby province to raise for reselling to abattoirs and farmers. His wife has been a fruit seller for two years. Mr. Mao is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase additional cows to raise for resale.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Leab

texts.en:
Mr. Leab O., 55, and his wife, Mrs. Saroeun Kot, 48, who live on an Island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1985 and have two sons, both fully employed. Leab has repaired motorcycles for many years, a skill he leaned from technical school in Phnom Penh, while Saroeun has been selling pork in the village for almost 10 years.

Leab’s house is on ground lower than that of his neighbor’s house, resulting in flooding during the rainy season, so he is requesting a loan of $500 to raise his house’s grade and expand the pork selling and motorcycle repair businesses.

loans.use: To raise the grade of his house and expand the pork selling and motorcycle repair businesses.

loans.name: Sokhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeun L., 25, and her husband, Mr. Sophal Mov, 24, who live on an Island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 2001 and have two sons.
 
Mrs. Sokhoeun and her husband have been silk weavers for 10 years, selling their products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. 

Now Sokhoeun is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase silk material for the weaving business and to build up the grade of the ground upon which her house sits, as it currently floods during the rainy season.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and raise the grade of the ground upon which her house sits.

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru:
Matluba J. is a doctor and works in a nearby hospital. In addition to working at the hospital, she operates a small farm. She works very hard in order to sustain her family. Her husband went to Russia for work and left her alone with their two children. Matluba decided to apply for a loan and buy a calf. This would be a small investment. After the calf grows up, Matluba will be able to sell it. She plans on repaying the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Джобирова Матлюба – врач . Работает в районной больнице. Живет в районе Рудаки. Кроме того , что она работает в больнице , она еще и имеет небольшое хозяйство. Ей приходится много работать для того , чтобы обеспечить семью. Она замужем . Но муж ее уехал в Россию на заработки и она осталась одна с двумя детьми. Матлюба решила получить кредит и купить молодую корову. Это будет небольшим вложением. После того как корова вырастет , Матлюба сможет продать ее.Погасить кредит она планирует за 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Buy a calf

loans.name: Surayo

texts.ru:
Surayo N. lives in Rudaki, Tajikistan. She is 50 years old, married, and has 3 children. She works as an obstetrician-gynecologist at the nearby hospital. She wants to obtain a loan to buy a cow in order to be able to feed her family milk. She will also be able to sell excess milk to her neighbors. She will repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Нусайриева Сурайе проживает в районе Рудаки. Замужем и имеет троих детей. Возраст 50 лет . Работает акушер-гинекологом в роддоме района. Хочет получить кредит и купить корову.Купив корову она сможет обеспечить свою семью молоком. А если будет лишнее сможет даже продавать соседям. Погасить кредит планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap V., 47, and her husband, Mr. Sary Ma, 42, who live on an Island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1990 and have four children, one son and three daughters. Three of their children are in local school.

Mrs. Sopheap has been a silk weaver for over 20 years, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her silk products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh, Mr. Sary drives a horse cart and is also a Khmer traditional musician. Mrs. Sopheap is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat U., 34, and her husband, Mr. Ty Soung, 36, who live along National Road Number Six about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1994 and have four children, two sons and two daughters, all attending the local school.

Mrs. Sophat has been selling steamed corn in the village for four years, while her husband drives a taxi, carrying people from Kampong Thom Province to Kampong Cham Province. Currently his taxi is broken, so Sophat is requesting a loan of $500 to repair it.

loans.use: To repair her husband’s taxi.

loans.name: Sophat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophat N., 53, and her husband, Mr. Ul Bos, 54, who live on an Island on the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1978 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Two of their children are in local school and another drives a horse cart. Their second daughter is married.

Sophat has been a silk weaver for over 20 years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her products to the middleman in the village, who then resells them in Phnom Penh. Besides conducting the weaving business, she also farms. Ul also farms and produces horse carts to sell. Sophat is requesting a loan of S1,200 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Gulnoro

texts.ru:
Gulnoro V. lives in a village of the Rudaki district, Tajikistan called Dzui Bodom. She works as a nurse in a hospital. Her salary is not very large. There was a very happy event that has just recently occurred in her family - her granddaughter was born, which is why she wants to buy a cow. This will give her the opportunity to feed her granddaughter fresh milk. But to be able to buy the cow, she needs a loan that she plans on repaying within 12 months. Gulnoro is married and has 4 children.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Вазирова Гулноро проживает в районе Рудаки в поселке Джуи Бодом. Работает медсестрой в роддоме. Получает небольшую заработную плату. Сейчас в ее семье произошло радостное событие . У нее родилась внучкав и поэтому Гулноро хочет купить корову. Это даст возможность кормить младенца свежим молоком. Но для того , чтобы купить корову ей необходимо получить кредит, сроком на 12 месяцев. Гулноро замужем и имеет четверых детй.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Habiba

texts.ru:
Habiba N. lives in the city of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. She works as an obstetrician-gynecologist in a hospital in Rudaki. In addition, she works as a cosmetics retailer. She works as a distributor of Mery Key brand cosmetics. In order to obtain these cosmetics, she needs to pay up front for them. Habiba has a small sum of money to buy cosmetics, but wants to increase this income with the help of a loan. The loan will help her attract more clients and increase her income. She plans on repaying the loan with 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Нарзиева Хабиба жительница города Душанбе . Работает акушер-гинекологом в роддоме района Рудаки. Кроме того занимается торговлей косметики . Работает дистрибьютером фирмы «Mery Key». Для того , чтобы получить товар необходима предоплата. У Хабибы имеется небольшая оборотная сумма , но она хочет ее увеличить путем получения кредита. Это поможет привлеч новых клиентов и зарабатывать больше. Погасить кредит она планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Buy and sell more cosmetics

loans.name: Saily

texts.ru:
Saily M. lives in the village of Vahdat, Tajikistan. She is a widow with 4 children. She does not have a job but supports her family by working with livestock. Now, she wants to buy another cow for its milk. She will be able to sell this milk to neighbors and feed her children. To be able to buy this cow, she needs a loan that she plans on repaying within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Dan Ostrovsky, Kiva Volunteer.

Махмудова Сайли живет в городе Вахдат. Вдова с четырьмя детьми. Нигде не работает , но для того , чтобы прокормить детей занимается животноводством. Разводит бычков , для продажи. А теперь хочет купить дойную корову для того , чтобы получать молоко. Получаемое молоко сможет продавать соседям , а так же поить им своих детей. Для того , чтобы купить корову она должна получить кредит сроком на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch Y., 56, is married and lives with her husband, Chhem Cheng, in the Kampong Cham province. They have four children, but they have all been married and moved out of the home. Touch is a farmer who typically makes US$2.30 each day, while her husband collects palm juice and refines it to sugar palm. Sugar palm is considered to be very delicious and is very popular among Cambodians. He takes the sugar palm and sells it in the local food market, making US$1 each day. They would like to see their income increased, but do not see a lot of room for expanding their current businesses. Touch Y. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase some land close to the market so that she can open up a grocery store. She believes this investment can allow her family to improve its current economic condition and raise her standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase land to open grocery store

loans.name: Yin

texts.en: Yin L., 58, lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Tob Tang, and their five children. She works  in the fields as a farmer as she has done for the last 28 years, typically making US$1.50 each day, while her husband raises ducks and makes US$2.50 each day. She has asked for a loan of US$600 to expand her husband’s business and to hire a farmer to work her land. With US$400 she would like to purchase some more ducks for her husband to raise and sell in the market, leaving her US$200 to hire a farmer to work her field. She is an elderly woman who has concerns about her health and would not like to spend too much time out on the farm. She believes these two investments can both increase her family’s daily income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase ducks; hire farmer to work land

loans.name: Chrek

texts.en: Chrek O. lives in the Kampong Cham province with her husband, Daoy Nat, her elderly mother, and her two younger sisters. She goes to the market each day and sells her handicrafts, making US$1.50 each day, while her husband works in construction. Her husband typically makes US$1.50 each day as well, but feels that he could increase his income and improve his business through the purchase of some new construction tools. Chrek O. has asked for a loan of US$700 to purchase these construction tools for her husband and to expand his business. She believes that this will be a good investment for her family, and it provides an opportunity for her to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase construction tools

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay T., 45, lives in Kampong Cham with her husband, Thoeun Thun, and four of their children. She works in the fields as a farmer, typically making US$1 each day, while her husband collects palm juice and makes US$1.50 each day. Collecting palm juice is a common practice in Cambodia, as the juice can be used to make palm sugar or many other products. Two of their children are also employed, one works in the local garment factory and another helps the father collect palm juice. High inflation has hurt many Cambodians economically over this past year and this family has been seeking out ways to diversify and increase their income. Lay T. has asked for a loan of US$250 to hire a cow to plow their farmland. She believes that this can increase the quality of her crops and increase her harvest as well. This investment provides her an opportunity to increase her income and improve her standard of living.

Lay T. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Thoeun Thun, is pictured above.

loans.use: Hire cow to plow farmland

loans.name: Kiemmiddin

texts.ru:
Kiemmiddin S. lives in the Vahdat district. He is 38 years, married and has four children. He has a higher education and works as a teacher in a secondary school. Besides teaching, he practices animal husbandry. He breeds and raises cattle that he then sells at a marketplace. Kiemmiddin needs the loan to purchase an additional bull, which he can raise and sell for profit, needed for his family. He plans to repay the loan within 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Шарофиддинов Киеммиддин житель Вахдатского района. Возраст 38 лет , женат и имеет четверых детей. Образование высшее . Работает учителеми в средней школе.Кроме того занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно-рогатый скот , который после откормки продает на базаре.Хочет купить еще одного бычка , которого так же после откормки он сможет продать и получить прибыль , которая так необходима его семье. Получив кредит он сможет приобрести бычка , а погасить кредит он планирует в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a bull

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru:
Fotima A. lives in the Gissar district. She is 55 years old, married and has five children. To support her big family, Fotima sells cold beverages. She has a retail outlet where fountain and bottled beverages are sold. She would like to purchase an ice-cream refrigerator in order to increase her business profit. Fotima wants to obtain a 12-month loan for this purpose.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Абдухоликова Фотима жительница района Гиссар. Возраст 55 лет. Замужем и имеет пятерых детей. Для того , чтобы прокормить семью, а она у них большая , Фотима торгует холодными напитками. Имеет торговую точку , где прдает напитки на разлив и бутылками. Для того, чтобы увеличить прибыльность бизнеса она хочет купить холодильник для хранения мороженного. Для этой цели Фотима хочет получить кредить сроком на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Zinatoy

texts.ru:
Zinatoy R. lives in the Gissar district. She is 24 year old, married and has no children. She works at home sewing bedding to order. She also makes wedding outfits. In order to grow her business, Zinatoy needs to procure material, which requires financing. This is why Zinatoy decided to obtain a loan of $450, with a repayment term of 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Рузиева Зинатой жительница района Гиссар. Замужем , детей не имеет. Возраст 24 года. Работает дома. Шьет постельное белье на заказ. Кроме того шьет на продажу свадебные комплекты. Для развития бизнеса необходимо закупить материал. А для этого нужны финансы. Поэтому решила Зинатой получить кредит в размере 1500 сомони , сроком на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase material

loans.name: Fotima

texts.ru:
Fotima Sharapova lives in the Gissar district with her family. She is married and has four children. She is a teacher at a Gissar secondary school. Besides teaching, Fotima supports her family by selling food products. She has a small store near her home. Fotima wants to increase product turnover by obtaining a loan. It will help her raise her income. Fotima plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Шаропова Фотима проживает в районе Гиссар. Живет со своей семьей. Замужем и имеет четверых детей. Работает учителем в средней школе Гиссара. Кроме того , чтобы обеспечить семью она занимается торговлей продуктов питания. Имеет небольшой магазинчик рядом с домом . Хочет увеличить товарооборот, путем получения кредита. Это поможет ей увеличить доход . Погасить кредит Фотима планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase product turnover

loans.name: Nafisa

texts.ru:
Nafisa S. lives in the Gissar district. She sells portiere fabric and has a retail outlet in the Gissar market. Her business is growing, but Nafisa wants to increase the goods turnover. She decided to obtain a loan of $600 for this purpose. The money will help her bring in new goods and attract new clients. Because Nafisa has been working in this business for 27 years, her extensive experience helps grow and lead the enterprise in the right direction. Nafisa is married and has seven children. Although, her family is large, it is very harmonious. Nafisa plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Собирчонова Нафиса жительница района Гиссар . Занимается торговлей партьерной ткани . Имеет торговую точку на рынке гиссара. Бизнес развивается , но Нафиса хочет увеличить товарооборот. Для этого она решила получить кредит в размере 2000 сомони. Это поможет завести новый товар и привлечь новых клиентов. Занимается она этим видом бизнеса уже 27 лет. Поэтому ее опыт помогает развивть деятельность в правильном направлении. Нафиса замужем и имеет семерых детей. Семья большая , но жвут они все очень дружно.Погасит кредит она планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Viviane

texts.fr:
Viviane A. was born on December 2, 1974 in Cotonou and is the mother of two children, Christiane (age 10) and Ariane (age 3), who are both in school. She is married to T. Justin ZOUNDA, a tile mason, and has been residing in Sènadé, a working-class district of Cotonou, for two years. Her business of six years has been in selling school supplies, damask fabrics, shoes, and ladies' bags. Currently, this business enables her to support household expenses, since her husband was a victim of a traffic accident. Ms. Viviane A. is on her third loan and has always demonstrated her credibility. She isn't currently managing to meet customer demand, which grows continuously, which is why she is requesting this loan in order to meet the expectations of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Dame A. Viviane est née le 02/12/1974 à Cotonou et est mère de 2 enfants Christiane âgée de 10 ans et Ariane âgée de 3 ans toutes scolarisées. Elle est mariée à ZOUNDA T. Justin carreleur et réside à Sènadé un quartier populaire de la ville Cotonou depuis 2 ans. Elle exerce comme activité la vente de fournitures scolaires, de tissu basin et des chaussures et sacs dame il y a 6 ans. Cette activité lui permet actuellement de supporter les charges du foyer parce que son époux a été victime d’un accident de circulation. Dame A.
